author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
If I was in charge of newcomer's career in Mastering based on everything I've learned I would say

1) Focus 100% of early efforts on getting the best speaker/room combo you can muster in place (forget all other gear for now except a functioning computer). Note I didn't say "most expensive"

2) Next spend as much time as possible listening with the best listeners you can get access to (other engineers, music fans, kids)

3) Ignore almost everything you read and watch on the internet about the topic of Mastering 

4) RIngfence your time developing and understanding techniques away from when you are actually working on music

5) Maximize your availibilty to the music (keep distractions, overheads, gear envy, fear etc to a minimum)

6) Now listen as widely as you can, to every genre - listen for details, listen like a fan, zoom in, zoom out, zoom in again

7) Love everything you touch. You don't have to like it, but you've gotta love it. Love is a quality of attention. Attend to the music with generosity, as you would a child, or grandma, or a precious butterfly

author: masteredbyjack
content:
This is great info. In a follow up to this, as a wonderful surprise, had my master picked in a shootout against an engineer who is leagues ahead of me.

My master was 1.6db quieter, and the artist actually liked the space it gave (it is still plenty plenty loud). Just was interesting that this artist had the understanding of really what they wanted, how it mattered to his art, etc.

Other guys master sounded great too, just really hot and dense dense. which I feel 9 times out of 10 will win because explaining the trade offs and benefits of loudness (and having it understood) is very hard, but this felt like an artist really leading with their vision, not concern with the loudness stuff…how he articulated it to me confirmed that. Pretty cool, regardless of outcome

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: An easy and often overlooked solution is just to do a volume ride *into* the limiter. It's diving for huge gain reduction and you can make it's work easier but just carefully shaving off a few dB on the way in. It will still keep it's shape an feel, likely match the mix ref better and avoid the crunch

author: Rollmottle
content:
Been trying to think of a way in to the question about what I did without being completely frustrating or giving a list of moves that don't mean anything outside of the context of being in my chair, hearing what and how I hear.

This process for this song is like any other...listen for what the song needs and act accordingly. That's the frustrating answer but it's also true. What did you do? "I mastered it." lol

But I know that's not what you're asking. For a track like this, I'm primarily focused on the vocal and how it's sitting and feeling. The vocal performance is incredibly dynamic and intimate. This one had some ringy stuff through 2.5k and in the upper mid range that I felt was detracting from the "fireside" intimacy. The goal was to take off some of the edge without stepping on the presence. That was a combo of RX and EQ. 

On this song, I did an analog pass because I am usually able to manage to get the balance of presence and de-edge I'm looking for very quickly. Since time was of the essence here, that was the move. Couple of moves on Equilibrium digitally before the Gyraf and Porter Grinder in the analog chain. The "trickiest" thing I did here was flip the Porter Grinder into M/S to bring the vocal closer into the center (by cutting!) and to push the mellotron and atmospherics to the sides (by boosting). All very subtle stuff.

So, there were some moves here, but the moves were all in service of the feeling the song was telling me it needed. We talk a lot about monitoring here. When you can connect to the song and walk around inside of it, it's much easier to know what you need to do (or not to do) to bring it to life.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Very important for working with younger artists - don’t ask them for notes, ask them how it feels. If you create a space for notes they will feel compelled to fill it, often while creating doubt. When you ask how it feels their response will tell you everything you need to know

author: Tim O’Sullivan
content: "The only remaining possible refinements are very small things (like a tiny polish in the 1.5–2.5 kHz area if needed, or a half dB here or there  — very subtle — just to add a tiny bit of forward energy without adding any brightness or harshness - This is not a brightness move — it's a micro-presence move). The midrange gains definition without aggression and a touch more confidence and articulation without getting harsh. The vocal feels more emotionally present. The whole track feels slightly more awake.I t could elevate the “mastered” feeling by 5–10%."

author: markmaclure
content:
You can read the patent for IRC here :https://patents.google.com/patent/US9225310B1/en?oq=Audio+limiter+system+and+method+izotope+US9225310B1
Basically the signal is processed multiple times with different attack and release times, then compared to the original signal. Each attack/release time is given a distortion and masking score and the best score is selected. The different IRC modes prioritize different types of scores (eg. IRC I prioritizes low pumping and distortion, IRC II is similar to IRC I but prioritizes transients more, etc). 
Izotope is a little cagey on the exact process they use to arrive at each IRC mode, but the manual does a pretty good job of explaining how each mode feels. IRC IV Transient is basically a multiband version of the other IRC modes that prioritizes transients, although Izotope says IRC V is its first multiband limiter in Ozone, so there is maybe more to the story there

author: Slow Hand
content:
If I may be so bold, I'd like to take a shot at articulating what I see as an ethos that I perceive throughout your responses:

At the essence there is a strong need to observe something for what it actually is and to understand it on its own terms. To look on something with soft eyes and not allow oneself to lean on lazy prejudgements that would prematurely assign a work to a category that aligns with our expectations of what we *think* it is or ought to be.

This can mean observing the idiosyncrasies of a thing and not making the mistake of writing their qualities off as mistakes. To instead see those qualities as features to be preserved.

This also means not falling into a trap of thinking "Oh this is a pop record, so the high-end need to be shiny" or "this is a hip hop song and needs slamming bass" or other such cliches.

Fundamentally it is about listening. Not a technical listening or a listening for where a thing fits in comparison to others, but the kind of listening and perceiving that takes the time to empathize and feel. To understand intent. The kind that ushers a work down the path that it is telling you it needs to go down.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think it's a blessing to get feedback about how you're fucking up. True, it's challenging at first, but it's the fastest way to building a good intuition and make the best moves.

My last girlfriend was very vocal about where she thought my shortcomings were. Where I was undeveloped and where I was not meeting her expectations. The kind of stuff that might make some people crumple under the pressure. While that could be a little exhausting at times I was happy to have it and accepted it in the positive spirit in which it was given. 

If you're lucky enough to get true signals about things then hold onto them tight because that's the path to positive growth.

author: nachomaquieira
content:
I feel like over this past year I learned to process a lot less in a more intentional, musical way. Putting my ego aside, reading situations better, knowing when small tweaks are enough and when it’s time to go deeper and be more proactive, always in service of the music and the people I work with, their personalities, and the context.

I mastered around 450 songs while raising a newborn at the same time, and I also managed to get more organized with my schedule and work more efficiently.

This growth is 100% tied to everything I’ve learned through the exchanges in this Discord. Forever grateful to everyone who contributes daily ❤️

author: LAPhill
content:
"Honor the intent of the feedback" being the crucial part of maturing in your craft. Reading between the lines of the feedback. "This chorus needs to hit harder, turn up the crash on the downbeat" might actually mean that the 4 bars leading up to it are too big, masking the lift you should be feeling, or there's a synth pad hanging over the bar and making things mushy. The client can identify where it's not working, but not so often why. And that comes with reps and an open mind. 

But also sometimes you just need to turn up the fucking crash.

author: Rollmottle
content: I wish I could launch this "-14 LUFS" thing into the fucking sun. I am working on a project for my friend, who is putting out a band’s EP. He asked me to master the two remixes he and another friend did. The other tracks were mastered by somebody else. This is a cosmic disco, dance project. It’s got grooves and kicks. I pull the tracks into the session and all the tracks are mastered to -1TP and -14LUFS. Completely inappropriate for the material and feel.  The remix MIXES are louder than the masters. The person who mastered the other tracks is entrenched in “they will just get turned down anyways so doesn’t make sense to make them louder” camp. I explained to my friend why that is completely wrong, but ultimately can’t be my battle to fight.  I erred way on the conservative side for the remixes and bristle at the idea that we’re short changing the material because somebody who doesn’t know any better read something somewhere on the internet.

author: Paris Lee
content:
I’m not really qualified to speak from any technical standpoint of anything discussed here, especially among the giants and don’t want to look stupid …but as someone who DJ’d House, Techno, Drum and Bass etc back in the late 90’s as a teenager in LA on Vinyl (I’m 45 now), watched the transfer to CD’js…(no idol of mine has touched a vinyl in 20 years) and masters for modern EDM artists, I feel like I can speak with some authority about, I dunno, *something*…Back in those days, I guess Ill just say there were a lot of factors that influenced what sounded so good about that era, and what producers did then. The dynamics, combined with the *type of low frequency* content of those genres at that time, along with DJ’s who knew what the fuck they were doing, along with sound crews who worked the rave circuit and were continually hired and worked with the same DJ’s, all contributed so much to this magic rave Vinyl era.
There’s nothing that touched those deep kickass lows back then, But That was the style! 
So much has changed. Producers back then got their loudness from pushing analog desks into the red, Simple Mackie desks, stuff like that. But We moved to an all digital world. I remember when the first pioneer digital DJ mixers came out, I’d put a vinyl on and just be like…this is shit! where’s my headroom?!?! the frequency distribution of the music has also changed, DJ’s also got more concerned with jumping up and down and clapping rather than mixing and gain staging. Clubs started putting limiters on the systems 
Most of these kids doing EDM at high levels-really don’t even need ME’s at all! Their mix busses are so super complex. If they took that stuff off, I’d be totally lost. But they like a little analog processing in a lot of cases. Loudness, they *don’t need*
Clipping, limiting, whatever, it’s the modern thing- If i can help I can- and I tell them not to change a thing- just back off the limiter until the exact moment where the track loses the vibe. Then I go.

author: Victor Garcia
content:
100% red flag. I experienced here a similar situation with what I think it is the best plant here in Spain. Of course they don’t cut in house but they send to cut to a very good engineer in Europe outside Spain. A VERY good decision for their business. I recommend all my clients to hire them because the results have been always super good. But… one day I got a PDF from the client asking if my masters had been through that PDF specifics. And this PDF was made by the spanish plant.
I just called the plant asking if that pdf was done by their cutting engineer of choice and they told me it wasn’t.
It was just a guide made by them they send always to their clients just “in case”. 
We chat for a while (so friendly and honestly) and told them if they could talk directly to their cutting engineer and ask for her/his opinion about that pdf.
One day later they just called me to say that will not send it again because the cutting eng said it was a non sense.
I’m happy with it because it was all done so friendly (both ways) for the sake of the art.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Oh man. I’ve had this happen to me twice. With BIG mastering guys. Greg Calbi mastered a mix of mine once and it came back STUPID hot, distorted, unreasonable. We ended up getting it there, but it can be disheartening. 

My approach is always contingent on my relationship with the artist. How much do they trust you, how much do you want to continue working with them, etc. @Rollmottle is always great with his words, and that kind of approach is key to get the conversation started. I also find that having an alternative master for the artist to listen to is helpful. Rather than explaining what’s wrong, just being able to say “I think this direction might serve the music better…” 

That being said, if the artist is asking their friend to master it, you might end up being the most professional person involved in the record. And you can see that as a responsibility, or an excuse to stfu and move on. If you’re proud of the mix you can always post THAT version on your platforms. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: cian riordan
content: Yeah I think that's a reasonable emotional response. I was working with Slash and just curious about his Les Paul -- the Les Paul -- and was asking him questions about it. He picked it up, played a few bars of sweet child of mine after he explained its history, then handed it to me and said 'wanna try?'. I held it and played a few riffs... wasn't like Slash changed my life or anything... but the weight of that instrument in my hands just felt *intense*. Similar feelings around Chris Thile's mandolin, or Stevie Wonder's piano... shit, every time I'm at Annie Clark's and pick up one of her guitars. It's inspiring to connect an instrument with its musical output, and ultimately it's emotional connection with yourself.

author: cian riordan
content:
Where have I heard this fear argument before? 🤔

“So much mastering (and production) is lead by Fear.   We see it with high mids that yell at you like an insecure billboard (fear of being ignored), or a thin low end that's afraid to clip anything (perfectionism is fear), or an overly compressed record that's afraid to not be "competitive" ... all Fear driven decisions, all failures IMO.

Love is the energy people want.  And bravery.  Artistry is at least loving and brave.  People want a leader to look up to and inspire them to be greater than they are, they want a real artist.   Playing it safe is what they do in life, perfection in the box is easy now, anyone can do Fear based productions.  People want something real.   Mastering that is fear driven feels like a product, manipulating them, not authentically connection and uplifting. 

On your record I have actually expended dynamics, some songs needed more than others.  More open, still vibey.”

WHAT shower? WHAT...anything? These devices change year over year, and incredibly hard to pin down, often have massive peaks and valleys in response. author: Slow Hand
content:
When it comes to loudness, a big unlock happened for me when I realized that a lot of perceived loudness comes from the frequency balance of instruments or groups. There's a sort of "center of gravity" for the frequency of instruments. Individual instruments did not need as much low end as I once thought. I realized that I could push more energy up into the mids and upper-mids. Instruments could be leaner and biting. Much more than I thought tolerable. This has a few positive effects:

1. The sounds will cut more and be articulate in the mix (if desired).

2. Low-end buildup is the first thing that's going to hit your limiter. Shifting the energy up the frequency spectrum buys you more space before your limiter kicks in. Thus your overall mix can be louder.

3. Your low-end instruments will no longer compete to feel powerful. Therefore they do not need to be as loud in an absolute/voltage sense. Meanwhile, your midrange-y instruments that were once lean and bite-y in isolation are supplemented by your low-end instruments and feel whole again.

author: Andy Lawson
content:
Just reading all the mastering/mixer chat above. In my world I am generally the one communicating with the ME (either being mixer or producer/mixer). Over time I’ve just taken to this being my roll. It definitely takes up more of my time without upfront payment but I feel that comes back to you with trust from your client.

My first listen to the master is what I try to work from. Does the song feel good? (It’s deeper than that but you get my drift). Communicate my thoughts with the artist and ask for there feedback. (I feel like me giving the thumbs up can really elevate their fears and listen freely 🤞)

Reasons for being the middle man
 1. I hopefully can communicate well with both (translating what the artist may want into actual terms) 2. Taking the stress away from the artist 3. taking stress and needless revisions away from the mastering engineer..
4.hopefully a better end product!.

That is where I’m at currently but always open to evolving

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
@Rollmottle already gave a great answer here. I want to re-state and co-sign what he posted 

1. Don't try and remove what you can't hear. Never going to end well. There is no general rule sub 30hz so don't try and preemptively deal with something if you're not even sure it's an issue
2. If you do need to deal with a low end issue, deal with it at the source, instead of the 2-mix if you can
3. If you're dealing with it at the 2-mix level, gentle shelves will do less harm than steep cuts

Ok. Now to a thornier aspect of your question - does throwing away super low end information help us with loudness?

As I’ve said many times here our typical goal is not just maximum loudness. The goal is really high perceived loudness, and low measured loudness (to avoid being turned down too much by normalization), all while remaining musical and true to the intent of the song

Perceived loudness is primarily driven by arrangement (less elements better), distortion (more distortion makes things feel louder but at obvious cost) and frequency content (special attention needs to be paid to the 1500 to 6000 region I mentioned the other day). Super low end content doesn’t have too much of a direct effect on how we perceive loudness but of course it does have second order effects - huge lows will cause limiters to overwork and we’ll get into trouble with things sounding smashed sooner than we’d like

Ok, but what of measured loudness? Here it pays to have an understanding of how LUFS are actually calculated. I don’t know if there’s a neat summary video somewhere Dan Worrall style, if so please link it in folks. The definitive doc on LUFS measurement is here 

https://www.itu.int/dms_pubrec/itu-r/rec/bs/R-REC-BS.1770-5-202311-I!!PDF-E.pdf

author: eschirtz
content:
I hear you Ruairi, and ultimately you gotta make your own call on this. 

But I just wanna reassure you that our business is built around serving your type of workflow. Even if 99% of users don't give a shit about the perfect playback, we do. That's why we have that "lossless" switch. We'll never switch to AAC due to bandwidth issues.

The "constant upgrades" are often due to the ever changing landscape of browsers. Each client is often on a different browser, different device and different internet connection. It's our job to understand that landscape and push fixes to ensure we get perfect playback across all environments. 

That's part of the reason we built the iOS app, to be able to provide a more consistent playback experience when browsers themselves are the limiting factor, and so that clients can listen offline to take the network out of the equation. But I totally understand that you can't really ask a client to install another app on their iPhone. 

To my knowledge, Samply is still the only platform that lets clients stream full resolution lossless AND gapless track transitions in a browser. It's a really tough engineering challenge, but ultimately the backbone of our entire business. We're committed to continuing to solve this problem and evolve with the technology available.

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I will share words that are not mine (these words belong to @Nomograph Mastering )

Context is important here. This is an email that Nomogrpah wrote back to a client that said "Hey I love the master so much but I am a bit worried about how much it might get turned down ?" or something to that effect 

Response was 

"Glad you are feeling the master!

Re the level thing that is a complicated question. A few thoughts

Not everyone has loudness normalization turned on. It also doesn’t exist on Smart TVs, many streaming web interfaces etc

The different services all have different level norm targets (and even different settings within just Spotify) - and they change pretty regularly

In terms of absolute level when normalization is active what matters is arrangement (dense mixes sound quieter than sparse/spacious mixes), EQ (bright/mid range forward mixes sound louder than dark) and distortion levels (clipped/distorted mixes feel perceptually louder than clean). If I make a master a dB louder in mastering using just limiting for example, they just turn it down a dB more when it’s level normed.

So what does all of this mean? It means that every song has sweet spot where the EQ/tone, the arrangement and the overall clipping/limiting level works best and communicates the intent. That’s what we aim for.

You can use a site like loudnesspenalty.com to see what will happen but it will just drive you crazy and the only real way to meaningfully alter the result is to change the arrangement/mix or overall EQ a lot. On release day you can find 1000 records that are louder than yours if you want to.

If being the loudest is the intent - game everything listed above and you can “win”. If doing your unique thing and communicating a song and a performance is the goal then I think you are there!"

(posted with Nomographs permission)

author: Berlin
content: Depending on the lathe and how much tech is being implemented, the visual spaces are created either manually by giving the carriage wheel a quick manual turn by hand, or manually pressing a button on the lathe console at the correct times - this advances/moves the cutter head carriage along. Some lathes have automation and it can all be done automatically, but more often times than not, it's still manual. The cutting engineer is watching the cutting time and doing it by hand.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I immediately change the frequency graph to *Log* or *Extended Log*. This allows me to see the low-end and midrange with more resolution. It's the same reason most EQ graphs keep the octaves evenly spaced so that 50% of your freq graph isn't 10kHz and up. It gives you more resolution for the notes in the lower octaves.

As for FFT size or window shape, I never change it, but as Ruairi alluded to it requires an understanding of the physical limitations of FFT's. 

In short if you want very fine frequency information displayed you can change the window size and lose rhythmic information. But it you want very precise rhythmic visualization you have to sacrifice how much frequency information the FFT can display. So the ideal setting ultimately depends on what problem you're trying to solve.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Keep in mind I’m still very new to mastering compared to most here, but this has happened several times already to me.

I’d do it on goodwill. Ideally your workflow and back end systems would make this a very small lift. Unless it’s something wild, better to have the client have a wonderful experience, keep their momentum, don’t introduce doubt, double down on their confidence, etc.

I’m assuming it would be something like making sure the levels and overall tone are right if you’ve already mastered them all and they are in the same ballpark, but feel free to tell me if I’m wrong.

Also “cohesion” is massively overrated to me anyway, I much prefer a creatively interesting and varied listening experience if the music calls for it as long as we are not having wild level or EQ swings or something (sometimes it calls for cohesion to have the best listening experience IMO, so know that too!). 

I’ve had multiple instances where an artist’s new “single” release includes their several past singles I’ve mastered too. They didn’t tell me they were doing that, and I mastered each totally alone, just based on the song and their vision. And to be honest those collections sounded totally fine every time as a group of singles, mastered alone.

All that said, I’d definitely politely educate them on what it exactly entails so it doesn’t happen again in future, and so they can take it into account creatively.

But of course where you are in your career, the relationship with this client, etc all plays into this. Someone like @Nomograph Mastering could very well see this very differently than me

author: Berlin
content:
I would suggest not changing the program material/main master too much and just preparing the sides, delivering one file per side, along with the PQ/Cut sheets with the track marker times (again one cut sheet per side), doing the QC listen down after export, and delivering with your approval.

I think backing off the limiter is sometimes OK, but very program material dependent. Yanking the limiter off a hot pop master might change things too much, for example.

Additionally, whoever is cutting the lacquer, will likely be doing their own adjustments as they see fit.. so if you are concerned about it translating properly, I would get with a lacquer engineer that you know and trust so you can have a dialogue about it, if needed.

That being said, in my experience, great sounding projects/masters will sound good on vinyl if the cutting engineer knows what they are doing… no matter how much you try to help with the PreMaster.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So, say it's time to check out a new limiter. Put time aside to work with it, compare it to others, get a feel for it. Then if you think it may be suitable for a project you can deploy quickly and make a call

author: Edsel Holden
content:
For me, I would sum it up with the phrase "curated compliance". I will mostly ignore it and master to the best of my ability and then one of  two things happen - 

1 - they love it

or 2 - they say "more!" and that gives more permission to be a bit outside the bounds of a typical master

99.9% of the time it's outcome #1

There is something to be said about the insecure artist/team doing the best they can with their words to fill in what they perceive as bad spots in their work - and just saying with full confidence "yep got it" makes them feel heard and respected. But when it comes time to actually master you don't HAVE to do it to their spec, and then that leaves the space for option 1 to happen. They love what they made you just create the circumstances for them to actually accept it.

author: Rollmottle
content: Apple and Amazon are durable businesses. Spotify is not. Netflix will go under in the next 10 years too IMO.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
A few thoughts on all this.. I agree with @Nomograph Mastering that the top of funnel for Spotify isn't bringing in enough money to overnight increase the amount music rights holders are paid. However, I am not convinced Spotify couldn't raise their subscription price in certain markets. Netflix has successfully raised their prices many times over the years. I've been paying the same price for Spotify for close to 10 years (maybe it increased a dollar at one point, but not sure).

I do believe Daniel Ek and Spotify have earned some ire from the music community. Ek is a billionaire and the average Spotify employee makes close to $110k / year. You would probably need around ~1.5 million monthly listeners and ~3.5 million streams / month to earn an equivalent amount (master recording side sans publishing and no other income stream). There are maybe a little over 6000 artists that have that large of a listenership in the entire world out of conservatively 5-7 million artists on the platform.

There are many things Spotify could do to improve economic outcomes for artists / musicians. Here are a few in no particular order:
1) Allow artists to link to their own website. Believe it or not we can't do this. Your own website is the one piece of online real estate that you actually control. On Spotify, IG, Tiktok, etc... you are playing in someone else's sandbox.
2) Allow artists more control over their profiles and the way they are laid out. One thing that infuriates me is how Spotify sorts albums by popularity rather than release date. I would like to change that. This would be beneficial to promoting newer releases. As well all external links off of Spotify are virtually hidden on the 'about' page at the bottom of your profile making it harder for fans to follow you where you want to be followed.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
First of all Edsel, congrats!! Sounds like you crushed it. Warms my heart to see others in here succeeding.

I’m extremely green (just going on like 5 months mastering full time), and was sort of interested that you thought it was perhaps not cool to use the limited ref? I’m getting similar stuff (limited, heated ref, unlimited), and honestly I find I’m using the ref certainly some of the time and working from there. Sometimes there is just magic there, and while my chain may be “better” it’s also just different, especially when I can tell people are mixing into that ref chain.

I guess I just mention because going into my new “role” in mastering I made a very conscious decision to only operate on a binary: is what I’m doing making the record feel better to me or not? Is it becoming more of what it wants to be?

And throw out any notions of what I felt I “should” be doing.

In some ways being very new has given me a great creative armor, I am not afraid to lose and therefore do not feel bad or something if the ref is a better starting point than my chain or if I am doing very little.

I am fascinated in your perspective as someone who is a pros pro but in between where I am and where Ruairi is.

I’ll land the plane here…it seems like the fact that this song was “above your pay grade” sort of played into the fact that you were maybe seeking Ruairi’s approval to use that limited ref?

Do you think you would have approached using the ref any differently if you knew it was just some kid in a bedroom, or would you have still trusted that it was still the move to use it?

I ask myself this stuff a lot, since I’d like to think I’m always doing exactly what is right for the song, but of course many factors play into our decision making (insecurity, relationships, fear of losing a project, etc)

Sorry for the rant, but your story was very inspiring! Happy for you!!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
On that note, can't remember where I found this but a related piano recipe from Michael Brauer. Hoping he hasn't trademarked this one so the Discord doesn't get shut down.



"Remember the early Elton John records? Remember how his piano shimmered? At mediasound we loved that sound so a lot of us were always playing around with getting different versions of it. No lacquered hammers, no Dolby A off, just a combination of compression and EQ.


I only recorded Luther's voice, may he rest in peace, on that song along with "searching" and then mixed both. Luther was on a whole other level of singers. He walked into that session and listened to the song in the control room once, then he walked out into the studio with the lyric sheet in his hand. What you hear on"Glow of Love" and "searching" is his first fun down reading the lyrics from a yellow pad. No punches.


The piano sound you’re referring to is probably the same one that I did for Vandross on the “Never too much” song.


Ok, this is how you do it.

1. First insert an LA3A or LA2A (depending on the version of sound you’re going after) across the stereo piano tracks. The LA2A is good if the song is slow and the chords are quarter notes. The LA3A is good if the chords are faster with a harder attack like in “never too much”. Bang those meters and 
2. out of the compressor go into a couple of pultecs and push up..way up the 3 or 5 k on the low end and the 8 or 10 k on the high end. Don’t be safe. 
3. Now go to the desk EQ and start clearing out some of the muddiness and EQ up the remaining mids so that it just shimmers like a baby. 
4. When it’s done right, you can hear the harmonics riding up during each sustain.  
5. I remember hearing that song on the radio and man that piano was making me feel good all over. Sounds pretty simple when you know how to do it right?”

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Gonna check it after I am wrapped for the day! Thanks for sharing.

Another thing I think about a lot, and I believe posted about it before, was an old Bill Evans documentary where he touched on how to learn to improvise/etc...and his main principle was to essentially "play at your level", and accept that's where you are. So instead of playing a bunch of fast notes...play only a few very slowly and intentionally...his theory was that it will sound and feel the most authentic that way.

In a mastering context, I think about just taking the song was far as I can at my current moment...like I may note be a Ruairi or Dale or Rollmottle but I can still do things that I think sound good and add to the record. It may not be as far as I can go in a year, or 10 but it still can read very musical and cared-for! But it takes a lot of...shall we say self-reflection to accept that I'm not where I can be yet and live with it you know? Instead of trying to force something on a record that doesn't need it

author: Rollmottle
content: Circling back to double click on a point that's buried in here...the goal of reference tracks is to have stable points of reference you KNOW. Find tracks you think are "bright" or "dark" or "punchy" or "clear" or "vague" or "big" or "bassy" or whatever so you know what those things feel like for you, in your room and on your speakers. Imprint all that onto your brain and eventually you develop an intuition for where your target is as you listen, not only in your room, but anywhere.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
In modern record making clipping and limiting on the buss is a huge part of the overall sound and feel of a record. Kendrick for example never heard his productions, mixes or masters without it. Clipping has an energy in the kicks and snares that was built a certain way, limiting has rounding and smoothing characteristics and often "holds" the track in a particular way. You can't just bypass one , or the other or both without huge changes in groove, balance, tone and feel. (Swapping limiters for something *safer* can be equally damaging) 

What does clipping actually do? It creates square waves at the extreme (for the duration of the clipping)

What is a square wave? It is a fundamental with a bunch of odd harmonics trailing off in level

What happens when you low pass the square wave at the converter reconstruction filter, lathe low pass etc? It is no longer a square wave

Does cutting this no longer square wave to a disc for brief periods present challenges and cause extra momentary distortion? Yes

Is that trade off worth while? I believe so and have itterated on this belief across hundreds and hundreds of projects cut and pressed to vinyl and then compared carefully with the original digital files

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The TLDR is that given the trade offs of the medium getting the big picture right (the overall tone, feel, groove and density of the production) matters more than the extra distortion added by cutting less than ideal waveforms to disc

But mostly, disparaging the music that young people are aspiring to make feels pretty “get off my lawn.”

author: Rollmottle
content:
Been reflecting on the discussion here...

I just don’t subscribe to the idea that loud = bad. There’s a whole school of the online mastering discourse that holds this belief and it strikes me as disconnected from the mainstream. It presupposes that loudness comes at significant cost to the material in some way — which way? Emotional? technical? artistic?  Or that all material should be dynamic…which is, of course, not true. 

As Noah was getting at, some of my most vivid memories of live music both as a performer and as an audience member exist BECAUSE they were loud as fuck. Loud is in our DNA. There’s a visceral, tactile and emotional response to loud. Even if we’re talking about a “quiet” or more dynamic record, people will turn it up so they can feel it.

Good loud is within everybody’s grasp in 2025 and I love being able to make loud records louder, with minimal, if any, trade off. If I can deliver an appropriately loud master given the material with little compromise, I will. That’s exciting to me and not a bummer. It's what the vast majority of my clients are looking for. Of course if the record doesn’t call for loud, we don’t make it loud. But, I also don’t think excessive loudness is what’s making or breaking records.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
What comes to mind quickly is:

1. Listen to the file after the export from master session (many of us do this in RX)

2. Consider what deliverable is needed (default for me is to deliver sample rate of what it came in at, 24 bit).

3. Consider how high your output ceiling should be based on the type of arrangement, etc. True Peak could play a role in this depending on the type of record

4. If there are alts, make sure they are aligned and exactly the same length as the main mix (again easy to check length in RX)

5. If you are doing SRC (say they need a 48k and 44k 16bit deliverable) check the SRC file as well to ensure that the SRC did not introduce any overs — it will quantize them to zero if you dither after but best to check still

author: Øra Mastering
content:
Like many have writen here, I also make sure my clients are happy (if not thrilled) about their masters before I send the invoice. You have discussed why this is good for the clients experience, but I have noticed how my subconscious attitude for the project changes the few times people have insisted paying in front of the project. 

Usually I have a huge motivation on moving a project along super quick and making sure to have a fast turnaround - the faster I respond and make them happy about their music = payday, both in positive feedback and 💵. But there is really no pressure since I have only received files, they haven’t payed me anything. If the client has payed, I either find myself slacking bc it’s already payed OR stressing out big time bc they have payed and I feel a huge pressure on not f*cking up the project and the smooth creative process goes out the window. My brain works better with a carrot then a stick.

That’s why I have found I do my best and fastest work when invoicing after masters are approved. I am sure other ME’s brains are wired the other way around.

author: Øra Mastering
content: I work both hybrid and itb. When working hybrid, I try to keep the same settings for a whole album and do eq, de-essing and level automation pre analog if needed (on individual tracks). On some albums, for me, there is no way around tweaking analog settings per track, but I try to avoid it. When printing the album I use the print-time to casually listen to the album from start to finish to catch stuff I would like to adjust (one track lacks impact ect.). Final limiter is always post analog print and I do not print hot. This makes revisions a breeze 97% of the time, unless there is a new mix of course. Also easy to back of a limiter without reprinting if the client wants more dynamics or I want a more dynamic vinyl pre-master. Hope that made sense.

author: spectrummasters
content:
I do like that first record a lot , so my response is defo biased by simply really loving the song and the artist 

The second one is totally not my wheelhouse 

I just wanted to note/counterpoint  where it seems you’ve caught a little heat for asking : 

I think there’s real value in being able to discuss what we’re hearing without feeling pressured to adopt a particular emotional stance or to measure our impressions against social circles or market outcomes. Honest listener reactions, offered respectfully, are part of how we learn as engineers. We can appreciate the creators’ dedication and still talk openly about the sonic choices we notice — those things aren’t in conflict. 

People like Jeff Ellis casually state that the shaker is way too loud on ‘Beat It,’ and no one sees that as disrespecting Bruce Swedien — it’s just part of how engineers talk about records. An honest  critique isn’t an ad hominem attack; it’s how we train our ears and learn from greats 

Technically , I’m 💯 with Johnathan’s point about monitoring and Anthony’s  about leaning in . 

The enemy of art is indifference . I love that you care enough to ask .

author: Elaine Rasnake

author: ehutton21
content:
Not sure if my playlisting response implied otherwise, but I think we’re saying the same thing here but somehow we’re on two different ends of the coin. I *agree* with your premise…

As you touched on with data, there’s a reason iOS 14 changed the Facebook ad marketplace and why Meta continues to more or less neglect the end user experience of its platform—because the money now is in having a wide array of data & developing the best ML+AI processes, meaning the big three of Apple, Meta, and Google (Amazon too now I guess… make it four) only care if they can quantify you when you use their services, hence the animosity for tik tok when it emerged as a new player with a kickass algorithm. So with that in mind, it totally makes sense that music developments such as these (the “foisted-upon-us-by-the-overlords” kind) should be treated with skepticism, and from what I can see there’s more to atmos than just a flash in the pan, IMO. It’s just not a flash in OUR pan, as we’ve all kind of intimated. 

To thread this very, very tight needle back to atmos, and somehow mastering too, the development of atmos almost always seemed logical if it were done with regards to cinema and gaming—where locating a sound is what mattered most. Alongside atmos, we’ve seen a rise of virtual spaces and platforms post pandemic that coincides with a digital gaming boom—the most convincing case I’ve seen for why we’re even bothering with Atmos is a entirely complete VR/AR experience, which would give entertainment companies wild new ways to expand their horizons and possibly revenues, but like @Nomograph Mastering points out, subsidies are slipping and I’m sure that’s because companies are seeing what we all knew.  

Because as we’re all saying, not many an artist really give a shit about making atmos or making feel like you’re in the room—that’s a 5 AM stoner thought most musicians have and forget. I think companies will pivot to other entertainment mediums to integrate atmos.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I'm no Ruairi, but I think about this a lot too, interested in your perspective. The only thing I've ever been able to come up with is "I like it". Of course I do my best to take the vision of the project into consideration, where it is and the potential it has to go further...but it truly and always comes down to just asking myself "am I connecting emotionally, and do I like the music better as a listener than before".

On some level, we can only be what we are, if that makes sense. I can't master as well as I will be able to in a year, 5 years, 10 years. But I just do the best I can, when I feel connected to the record, it's done.

Have had quite a bit of stuff come recently, had to get it out quick. I also specifically practice doing very short masters (not for a client, just practice)...I find this lets me know where I am. Almost always just keeping on tweaking hurts the music, our objectivity, etc. Some of my favorite ones I've done were done in 10 minutes. And not because I rushed, because I just trusted my intuition. And I hope this doesn't come off as arrogant/etc but I deeply believe in my taste and what I like. I never question it. Luckily, people seem to agree with me so far. But unless you have that trust in yourself and are willing to put it on the line, not sure how anyone could really do high, high level work like Ruairi is (feel free to push back on this).

And sometimes, a "bold move" is to barely do anything. That takes a lot of trust and belief too.

 My issues almost always lie in me not being able to quite get it where I want to go. That's hard. But never about where it should go, if that makes sense. Sometimes I may be wrong, or people disagree creatively, which is great! That's information we can use to bring their vision to life more accurately.

One of my favorite coach speak/quote things from my football days was "you don't rise to the occasion, you default to your level of training". I find it's true. 

Thoughts on how you approach that?

author: Rollmottle
content:
This is a tough one. Couple routes I see. Depends on the relationships and how much it matters in the grand scheme:

1. Flip the burger and do the best you can with what you've got.
2. Tell your buddy to do better and what to fix to ensure the best outcome.
3. Bite a big bullet and fix it yourself.
4. Split the difference with your buddy. Tell him to prep stems and do a stem master so you can have access to "fix" some of it.

Would all depend on how much the relationship with the artist matters, if the song rips but the production is getting in the way, end goal etc.

I have done 1,2 and 4 to varying degrees. I'd probably start with 2 though and see what happens.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I'm still in learning curve here with you too...but I've found some personal mindset success just thinking in terms of "vignetting" certain things...like if I'm dipping some upper mids I'm really thinking I'd like to bring out some air and lower mids...like what do I want to shine light on and what I don't? What do I love about this and how can I bring it out in the most musical way? Often just boosting it isn't the most emotionally clear way in my (again, still limited) experience.

I think a lot of my mindset stems from also being really a producer/mixer at heart...I'm often also pushing things I find maybe a little off the beaten path and maybe "not right" but are musically interesting...I wonder if I actually would have put MORE emphasis on the horns in your specific case (not if they sound "bad" and annoying, but I sorta love stuff that's living on the edge as long as it's giving me a feeling).

I'm shocked sometimes how much the "problems" in engineer speak are actually things that I love about records and give them their character

author: Adam Thein
content:
Constant Bit Rate, Average Bit Rate, and Variable Bit Rate.

I usually choose 320kbps CBR personally!  The other modes are intended to save on file size further by setting the bitrate lower either by average or program dependently.  With the low cost of modern digital storage and internet speeds I always go for CBR!

author: Iwan Morgan
content:
Interesting response by Chris Gehringer in the new MWTM Q+A section: 

*"Dereck, You really hit home with this one.
I’m 99% ITB for over 10 years was well. I was more hybrid earlier on during my conversion period and now mostly all in due to my workflow and client time demands.

I definitely feel like i’m chasing Refs with the same plugins used by mixers and producers sometimes and don’t feel creative but that’s the game lately. I really feel this is the main problem. I’m not really happy when i’m pushed in that direction.
With almost everyone having the same plugins it’s very apparent that most masters in a shootout sound the same now. No surprises there.

Is Analog Better?

I recently bought a Terry Audio CEQ to try and change my sound and it definitely works. It has an amazing sound and color that cannot be found in most plugins. That being said it doesn’t work for me all the time.
Many of the projects i work on are so loud and pushed anything run through analog gear loses the “glue” that is in the digital mix.
I also just got a Sontec MES-432D9D from Make Believe Studios.
It actually sounds like the real thing to me. It has a much different vibe when using it. I find myself using different frequencies from other EQs.
Is That Better? I’m not sure yet but getting good results when i use both of these tools.

I think the most important part of my setup is that I’m very familiar with my plugins and know when to use different ones when necessary (its also so easier to try another one if you’re not sure obviously)
I’m constantly trying to stay fresh and not mail it in.

Not sure if there’s an actual answer for this but i hope i answered some of your question or at least validated our situation.

Chris"*

author: jordanmcleod_io
content: I'm no where as experienced as some of the other peeps in here, but have some thoughts. I think you kind of answered your own questions. $10 is crazy low and not sustainable for anyone, I'm not sure what that other engineer could actually be doing besides blasting tracks through Ozone. Since you are already cold emailing, I think your time could be better sent searching out artists who are in need of an ME and get your full rate there. If you took the $10/gigs, they would eventually be dropped anyways as more full rate gigs started coming in. If it were me, I would rather work the word of mouth game through the artists you are DMing and hopefully more gigs stream in that way via other artists, producers, or mixers. Put in the work now creating meaningful relationships and connections that can exponentially grow instead of the label path which seems like a dead end. I've been cold DMing artists with a freebie first song, I just started this month and it's a big numbers game, so I can't say for certain how it will go. But, because of the freebie I gave them, I am now talking with these different artists about mastering an album, an EP, and several singles at full rate. This is rhetorical, but how many cheap label songs would you need to master in order to get the same amount of money? So in short, if it were me, I would spend my time elsewhere creating more meaningful relationships with much more room to grow.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I generally don't do that, FWIW. 

The best producers I work for occasionally ask something specific (e.g. "we started putting Bloom on our mix bus, how do you feel once you recall it and start tweaking?"). Or for e.g. a drum bus w/ heavy processing they'll ask if I'm good to work w a stereo stem instead of the multis. But even that's a fairly rare exception. Mostly they've done what they like, they send it how they want to send it, and they want me to mix it.

There's one producer I work for who regularly wants more feedback. I find it hard to give. Because I wasn't there in the room, I don't know the limitations of the session. It's not helpful to try and impose my harmonic vocabulary or arrangement preferences on someone else's, and the sessions are never unmixable even when I don't think they come from an ideal starting point. And on a fundamental level I really don't like telling other people what to do or how to feel.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
It’s super subtle but always worth keeping a service ethos in mind

Even as an internal dialogue “I want this off my plate” feels different to “Hey, checking in to see if you heed anything”

The actual email to client will be the same, but the intent matters

Also sometimes the abrupt ending is the vibe, optionally add some silence on the end to give it some room to land.

author: Railtown Mastering

I feel like you've got to give it your absolute all and do your very best every time. I think you need to give yourself that confidence and trust in your work man! author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my side I always want to keep working with people -- you never know how the relationships evolve (I know you know this, you are more experienced than me). I just tackle the notes -- it's rare I would ever say it wasn't a great experience. I want to master as many records as I can. At the very most I would let them come back again, say it's not the right fit and suggest someone I know to be a good fit (I've done this before). But always with the art and their vision first, if I truly don't understand it.

That said -- I did get really close to walking on a recent project, we were way down a rabbit hole, I think I legitimately did 15 masters. And we were caught up on dither, comparing to pink noise, etc. It was wild. We got it across the line - but I went way out of what would be constituted by us as what the "mastering role" should say, because the music was great and I thought the artist could understand my perspective. And I think it actually hit, to refocus on the art and feeling. 

It's a fine line. Sometimes I get the impression that I do step out of what is supposed to be said by mastering engineers -- but people seem to connect with that on my side. 

Also if things are going that way I will just stream it to them -- often they are looking for control or are having a hard time making decisions -- something I see in this new crop of record makers who only have ever worked in a DAW. Hard to know without actually knowing the humans

Then again, many many times I get a note and it's great and insightful and I love it

author: James Cronier
content: Totally agree here as far as trying to meet clients  where they're at with odd feedback/requests. It's not my job to educate clients, and it's definitely not my job to tell them how to feel. It is my job to be an affirming creative collaborator and keep my portion of the relay race that is record-making on track. I've found the more I am open to the weird stuff the more I find cool ways to make things sound better. If I really don't understand something a 5min phone call with the artist or producer solves that problem. If things end up not to my taste, fine. If things truly seem to be going off the rails (like the sudden barrage of notes @thegreatcarsoni encountered) I'll often ask for more info: "hey, I see you've got lots of new notes, I'd love to chat and make sure I'm nailing things for you on my end." More often then not that'll result in a pleasent and productive discussion. Sometimes I end up doing the notes, sometimes the concerned party ends up nixing most or all of the new notes. My whole ethos as a mixer (and occasional producer or ME) is to let the artists and producers into my world and process. No secrets, lots of sharing what I'm doing and why when appropriate. People are not hiring me to mix, they're hiring me to be a creative team member. Being open to "crazy" notes and ideas is part of that sometimes.

author: Will Pragnell
content: You’ve shared words like these many times, and i can’t tell you how much they are helping me as i navigate the emotional rollercoaster of getting my first clients and sending out my first masters. Very much a sort of north star. Thank you!

author: Moses Mastering
content:
Haha, yes! I put all my energy into showing off what’s already there. I don’t worry about “pokey” things—if it pokes, that’s probably what they wanted, so I lean into it and showcase it even more. Nine times out of ten, when I trust my gut and focus on what the mix is doing well instead of trying to “fix” it, the client is way happier.

That’s a little part of my secret sauce! Highlight the things that are screaming, “Pay attention to me!” Unless, of course, the client specifically says, “The vocal is WAY too pokey,” or “The bass is too heavy.” But even then, I’ll tweak things in a way that amplifies the magic instead of shutting it down.

For example, I might boost the top end until the bass feels correct if they say the "bass feels too loud in the way the mix landed"  cause the bass is supporting so many other parts of the song...or adjust the sides or frequency range to smooth out a pokey vocal—without approaching from a ..let me target the vocal. Ill target other things to make that vocal not feel pokey in context because nine times out of ten theres a lot of magic 99% of the time in that vocal outside of the few times it POKES haha.. if that makes any sense. 

It’s all about amplifying the intention for me .. but thats me:) it makes sense to my ears that way.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
The norm for me across a lot of indie labels and all the Majors

- SD (Standard Definition) - 44.1 kHz 16 Bit WAV
- HD (High Definition) - Native sample rate of mix (44.1/48/88.2/96 kHz) 24 Bit WAV

Then depending on the project we'll have 
- Alts (Instrumental, A cappella, TVs, Cleans) at the HD sample rate & 24 Bit WAV

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Paris Lee
content: I think with Reference tracks it’s mostly: what makes you *FEEL* good! Not just like, what’s popular, or the loudest thing, or the most technically impressive…what gets you buzzed! Music is energy, a vibe…when you get that feeling of what sounds like a great record to you, that will transfer to your own mastering - when you can fully take the ‘lab goggles’ off when the sound is coming at you, and connect with the track on an emotional level- you’re done mastering the track.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I’m also usually a 1 limiter guy, and I’ve seen plenty of 1 limiter projects hit -4 LUFs and sound great, so it’s not like more = louder. 

In the spirit of not creating a dogma here, just yesterday I heard Randy Merrill say it’s not uncommon for him to stack 2 limiters with different time constants, keeping the musical groove in mind, with one doing 90% of the work and another doing 10%. I get the sense that he’s feeling the value of both fast and slow release on the same project, and he’s getting great results too!

author: Austin Gordon
content:
This right here. One of the most important takeaways I've received from conversations with musicians and engineers (especially newer/more inexperienced ones) is that they don't want to feel talked down to, like they're dumb, a burden, etc.

Part of being great to work with is being willing to meet them at their level, show humility, and exercise careful restraint in how you assert your expertise. You don't have to be the smartest person in the room, just the one that can solve their problem.

author: Berlin

author: Rob Domos
content:
First of all, that Ava Max record feels great to me. That opening crackle is pure vibe. Consider that “clean audio” isn’t the goal, but that casting the spell of a vibe is the goal. Distortion isn’t only for metal. 

Second of all, many of us here are personal friends with the teams who worked on these records. Let’s consider how we speak about other people’s work. Extremely dedicated people that we work with every day devoted themselves to doing a good job here. 

A loving disposition is good for it’s own sake, but even if you couldn’t muster any love in earnest, at least acting with an awareness of politeness towards our friends would be more in alignment with putting your best foot forward here

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Here’s what it comes down to. Very few people in the world are Max or Luke or Rick etc. 

In my life, even when I was the best musician in the room, and the actual hired on paper Director, the process and the outcomes both suffered when I dismissed feelings in favor of the art. 

When I started to consider music as the medium through which we connect with people, rather than people the medium through which we make great music, my work and my life got much better. 

I know it takes all kinds, and in this case I think both of our perspectives are important to hear cause some of these pansies need to buck up and some of these assholes need to chill tf out.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I have a take on this;

From the outside, "Audio-Engineering" seems very "tech". I don't need to tell you all that "tech" is and has historically been male dominated.  There's a lot of equipment, technology, etc, etc, and since the history of manufacturing musical equipment, recording equipment advancements, etc, dudes are the ones who felt like they could get into that and freely go for it.

The truth is a lot of what we do is artistic, musical, mental/psychological, dealing with people, service, etc. I think women are getting their feet in the door now in the actual industry more than ever before with a lot of support thankfully.

Maybe the asshats on gearspace or forums are still not leaving an environment where women feel comfortable, maybe there are people in smaller cities who are making it difficult, I don't know.

I teach at a trade school for audio engineering (teaching post production, voice over recording, SFX, commercial shit) and we have more girls now than ever before and it's amazing. They kick ass, always have, and they will be more and more apparent in our industry before too long.

author: Bonati12461
content: My spacing standards are also based on the old CD mastering days. Audio too close to a marker was in danger of getting a wee bit cut off when the CD would start. So, something like 150-200ms in the beginning and 100-ish for most everything else. Still ultimately do it by feel but build in this safety as well. Just don’t ram the marker right up against the fit bit of audio and you should be fine.

author: Nicky Howard
content:
I do something a bit like this! 

When working at the mix's native sample rate, my main limiter is usually set to -0.3 dB FS. If ISP control is needed, following this, I have a second limiter all zeroed with the ceiling set between 0 to +1 dB TP.

Delta mode on the second limiter is good for checking what this does. 

When the second limiter's ceiling is the same as the first (or the first is in TP mode), the triggering is usually rhythmic to the music. It's obvious and can eat transients. When at 0 dB TP, it's usually triggering much more randomly, making the ISP control much less obvious. 

If the music is slammed and the second limiter is too aggressive at 0 dB TP, that's when I push up towards +1 dB TP. TDR Limiter 6 is good for this as the ceiling goes positively. It's just not so good for actual limiting!

author: Rollmottle
content:
I don't know if there's really anything to do to break people who have arrived at mastering with mixer brain. In my experience, it's driven by deep insecurity and the best I can do is hear their concerns, remind them all the great things in their song and indulge the notes without breaking the whole thing or heading down rabbit holes that aren't worth anybody's time. It's often a balancing act "Well, I can't really do on my end that but I can try XYZ to see if that hits what you're feeling" -- even if I know a thing is technically possible. Sometimes that means a song goes to V7 that was done on V1. 

At the end of the day, I think these folks just want to know they are being heard and I'm not certain there's anything you or I could do better that would solve this other than accounting for more time for projects with stakeholders prone to this (aside from raising their rates or dropping them as clients of course).

author: Rollmottle
content:
The things to check vary based on the requested deliverables. If you’re not really doing this regularly, for you, I'd make sure you’re asking up front if there are alts or files for physical releases that you need to account for. Cleans, instrumentals, acapellas, sequence, overlapping crossfades, metadata, PQ sheets, less lims, vinyl, etc. all may start to matter to finalizing something. And if you haven’t accounted for the deliverable and the time it takes to prep and QC in your rates, well you may be in for some pain.

Others may have some of these steps in different spots, but for me, it's roughly:

1. Print approved masters at native sample rate and bit depth.
1a. < Deprecate un-used versions>
1b.  <SRC/dither to any other sample rates and bit depth requested>
1c. <Assemble any physical deliverables>
2. Listen to every single file you’ve printed & check any data
3. Deliver

author: Rob Domos
content:
To me, this oversampling stuff isn’t a case of “more is better but the massive computational increase for that little gain is silly”. If I thought it was better I’d just sell a kidney and get a super computer, but I think oversampling above quad rate actually sounds worse. Been puzzling as to why for a while. 

I’m confident at this point that it’s not that I like the sound of aliasing. Oversampling that high has this smoothing effect like when you crank the noise reduction on a photo that isn’t coming from the LPF or the decreased distortion. I’m a Dunning Krueger case when it comes to DSP math, but from the surface amount that I’ve drilled into it, it seems that there’s at least a handful of different ways of adding samples to a signal and none of them are completely free of cost to the signal. It’s possible that maxing that process to the ceiling incurs more of that cost.

author: Will Pragnell
content: All true statements. I realise when you frame it like that it sounds a little wild, so here are some other true statements for context: I have had many singles and EPs mastered (both my own music and others music when I ran a label). I have mastered singles and EPs (not as many). I know the client somewhat well, and they know exactly where I'm at in my mastering journey. I initially offered to do it for free but they said they'd be more comfortable paying, and I am very much intending to price appropriately for my level of experience.

author: Moses Mastering
content: I rarely will discount for more songs. I have learned the more songs often the "longer" it takes to make them all play nice with each other especially in 2025 where I might get a record that is from the label with 3 mixers, 13 songs over 3 years of single release then ep, then remixed, then all put together to be "the album". I  honestly can never copy and paste settings either 99% of the time from song to song which I think some clients assume, well you dial one in so the rest should be faster. Sometimes the record is super consistent and it is "faster" in theory, but due dillgence is still needed on every song start finish, then if you get the track list or sequence and its a little complicated or they got high energy next to ballads next to high energy etc. You have to manage how that flows as well. SO I find singles are "easy" ...EP are little harder..... LP to get out the door, with each song reaching its potential while feeling cohesive often takes more "time". So no discounts. I will sometimes discount the total budget if the people are good, music is good and the budget is not my normal rate. SOMETIMES though I ask them to save up haha... because most can and most have rarely thought about that.

author: Moses Mastering
content: 100% fades haha.. and if they get specific with fades .... it becomes a print-fest lol... I ACTUALLY started telling clients about three years ago. PRINT EXACTLY how you want it to start and stop. It will save us all time and actually help with LP becuase we have the pacing already which indeed impacts the ears ability to rest, reset, before the next song and where I need the next song to kick in volume wise to feel good.

author: Berlin
content:
I have my Alts in tiers of 3... Half rate for 3 Alts per track, you get up to 3 per track of your choosing, after that it's another half rate for another 3.

mp3s I would call an SRC master, or any file conversion for that fact, and charge for the Hour it takes to prepare and listen. If not a full LP, I charge 1/10 of the hour rate per track. 

I also do this for any deliverable.. DDP, Vinyl Premaster, etc.. Charge for the Hour to takes for each deliverable to prepare and listen/QC after export.

author: Moses Mastering
content: one persons perspective...I just have two flat rates, one for indie and one for label as it takes more time usually to get a project thru the door with deliverables and random talking heads who think the bass is too loud in their 2013 land rover on the bass boost setting that I have to listen too lol... BUT i ran numbers of time vs money etc about 9 years ago.. and the cost of running alts and the benefit of a flat rate vs explaining to clients cost, and nickel and dime or they come back later and then i had to charge etc. Its way easier for me to run it all right awawy and just call it done. You can make plentyyyyy of money by doing this method and you remove friction and the potential fear in their mind that theres always an upcharge. For me this has played out massively over 14 years of client loyalty and peace of mind. Its a time suck  .. i usuall do invoices during this time... ive done assistance etc.. over they years but then its me paying the assistant to run alts which  is not a high level skill and managing them on some level. Long term you can for sure make a killing just doing it yourself and also the client seems to really enjoy knowing its a turn key process. The  main thing for ths is making sure your charging a high enough rate to start with which isnt really "hard" .... its just a matter of presenting the value and sticking to your rate. Customer service is worth a LOT and especially with referrals. Ill get gigs just because of the above method. Time yourslef how long it takes to do the alts, work the numbers and youll find if your charging a "pro" rate.. its not a  problem. Now of course if you dont want to do it.. thats a different conversation and fine, get an assistant. ALSO RX batch and some other programs people mention can make it extremely fast with a few clicks of the button.

author: Paris Lee
content:
@Stefan Hi Stephen, this is a great question! 
There are two issues at play here: One the more obvious, sending the signal to multiple A/D’s, and then, maybe a little less obvious: the issue of how your system is being clocked, and whether the A/D you’re auditioning is exerting maximum performance based on these conditions. Personally, to feed multiple converters, I use a Maselec MTC 1x console. This offers two identical outputs. So the analog signal part of that is solved right there. There are other ways to address this problem like outboard switchers. 

But here’s the real problem, clocking. *Generally*, and when i say generally probably in almost 100 percent of cases, the A/D converter sounds its best when it is the master clock of your system. Of course there are *certain* converters that *may* benefit from external clocking, but I’m not jumping into that can of worms. You can read ENDLESS arguments on Gearspace about this. 

I’ll say up front that I think clock sounds best just getting transferred straight through the AES audio feed to your interface, vs using a BNC output to your system, but again, I could get pushback there, that’s my opinion. 

So- let’s get to it, you have two A/D’s running AES feeds into your interface. Now, on your interface itself- you need to choose what AES feed your choosing to Sync to- so you’re going to choose one aes feed, or the other. This doesn’t *preclude you* from solo’ing each feed in your DAW. But the main thing here is that when you audition one converter, you need to also go to your control panel of your interface and select that AES feed to sync if you really want to hear the correct sound. 

In sum, I would do it this way and record a 30-45 pass of each. Then audition them that way (i use comp lanes on the same track to achieve this).

Another possible way to do this is having an outboard aes switcher like a z sys and switching the converters to the same aes output. Hope this helps!

author: Calvin Lauber
content:
Hey guys- so I’m asking this question I guess in a mixing context but I know it’s a common function of mastering so I thought I’d post here. 

I always have an instance of ozone maximizer at the end of my chain that I mix into. I’m generally happy with the results/loudness I get and comfortable with the parameters, except I never really mess with the “character” which I suppose is the speed/release of the limiting? 

On a recent mix I slowed it down more than I ever would, which really just means making it slower at all from the defaul setting, I usually stick very close to it, and I really like how it made the pocket of my mix feel. But I guess, I have always understood people to use very fast release compression on masterbusses.. 

do you all find yourselves moving the character/release of the final limiter around pretty widely to get the right feel or are you typically keeping it quite fast?

author: Calvin Lauber
content: Totally. thats validating to hear thanks jack. it's such a simple concept (if it sounds good, it is good) but it's wild how sometimes that one thing someone tells you 10 years ago not to do, it just sticks in the back of your head. I know Ruairi speaks on this often but I'm working on removing fear from my listening and just doing what feels right.

author: hebakadry
content: I think time spent de-essing vocals and treating HF content in vinyl prepped masters overrides worrying about how much limiting there is in my opinion. The amount of limiting and how good/bad the cut is really pertinent on the program material itself.  Not the actual amount of gain reduction you are doing because the cutter will literally just turn everything down anywhere between 8-10dB before the signal hits the amps. Excessive sibilance, on a hyper compressed rock record with insane splashy over compressed cymbals and out of control HF information will result in the dull cuts you get back from most plants where you don’t have access to the cutting engineer.  They do this because they want to create a playback safe record and avoid a very expensive $10k mistake like blowing a cutterhead if their amp breakers aren’t calibrated right.  Instead of spot de-essing problem on one song or spot treating problem songs on a side, they will opt for broad stroke moves (HF limiting, EQ, global de-essing) and that can be a bit of death sentence to the quality of the cut and put everyone off vinyl as a format.  Which I think is an incredible format with well crafted engineering.  Also I strongly believe that every record doesn’t belong on vinyl…but that’s another convo.

I keep trying to accommodate the needs as best I can, because the client is so kind and this is a project he is very passionate about. The issue is that the publicist is asking for things that she isn't fully able to be very clear about (I think maybe because she is somewhat inexperienced and doesn't know what it is she actually needs), and it's starting to approach a level in which I'm providing a lot of stuff for no charge--even though at the moment, I'm swamped and starting to get a little stressed trying to squeeze other projects in and also trying to wrap this up and get the client everything he needs. For some background, I had to re-make the DDPs because the client changed some song title information after I had already done the due diligence of confirming with him that all of the information was correct. now, his publicist, who had originally requested embedded MP3s with all of the album/artist/sequence info and album art for the album and also five singles, is now saying she meant to say she needed wavs.

author: Halliemmelton
content:
I always send invoices for indie projects (especially if they’re discounted) up front but I won’t hold a project hostage or anything. If they ask for parts after all is said and done, same thing. 

Sometimes if it’s an indie artist but they’re paying full rate, I will send an invoice when I send the master or when they have approved; I’m a little less easy about it but it also hasn’t bit me in the ass yet, so we’ll see how long that lasts. 

If it’s a label project I always invoice after—and usually wait a bit to be like “if you don’t need any additional parts I can go ahead and send the invoice” and that prompts them to request parts so I don’t have a project floating around in limbo un-invoiced.

But all my regular clients pay straight away nowadays, had a few cases where they'd send me the payment for the project before I've had chance to write up an invoice!

Ugh that's so frustrating and I'm sorry to hear you're going through this. It's annoying when clients really try to take advantage of the whole "unlimited revisions" thing.
I've dealt with a couple projects like this in the past which led me to communicating with the client at the time of first round delivery that after three free revisions I will charge $25 per revision. This way you still have some opportunities to make adjustments but if they need more than three revisions, more often than not it was a problem with the mix and not the master.

I feel like when you send this next round of files back you should let them know that this is the last one you can provide without extra compensation for your extra work and time.
