author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
My Reaper workflow is to use the DDP marker formatting for every format's renders. (DDP, .wav, .mp3, even vinyl, etc...) 

Let's say you have your track markers formatted as : **#TITLE=songtitle|PERFORMER=artist|ISRC=666** etc., aside of the "!" marker at the beginning for the 2sec gap and the last "@" marker for the album metadata.
Your session is now ready for a DDP export.
Then, if you want to render .mp3 and/or .wav you have to use the wildcard : **$marker(#TITLE)[|]** in the file name entry, aside to other wildcards you'll need for folder structures etc. Also, the options :  "Bounds : All project markers" and "do not render files that are likely silent" are needed and will prevent rendering the empty first 2 sec marker.
To automatically include metadata in the files, you can use the same wildcards such as : **$marker(#TITLE)[|]** for Title,** $marker(PERFORMER)[|]** for Artist, **$marker(ISRC)[|]** for ISRC, etc etc...

With this method, you can, with one single workflow, render : DDPs, digital formats, and even vinyl, using additional regions. Once you have everything ready in render presets, it's super easy.
I recommend using the "WyattRice DDP editor" to easily edit the markers.
I've also made a script to automatically generate a .html "PQ sheet" file with timings, titles, ISRCs, etc, (both CD and Vinyl)

I hope it can help, English is not my native language, so feel free to ask for clarifications if needed.

author: Val ᶠʳ
content: I have a mastering project template with the grid set up in "Frames" with a frame rate of 75. It's basically for DDPs, but I generally do every other format with this grid setting to ensure CD compatibility in a single workflow.

author: ehutton21
content:
comfort & best range of flexibility is my criteria. I prefer having attack and release controls and being able to tweak it all accordingly, and that’s why i’m keen on ozone and boz—ozone fits so seamlessly in with the rest of my bus compression as well. everyone does mix-bus differently and for me the biggest thing i want my clipper to do is to catch the peaks that my bus compressor hasn’t dealt with as in full and provide a little more “push” without squashing anything. for me, i try to keep mix bus processing pretty consistent in terms of tools but vary the control settings to match the song. pro-q (pulling down very subtle things i don’t want), bus compressor, my quick little ozone chain, and then the boz clipper.

it varies from genre to genre on occasion but most of the artists i work with have a very consistent “radio friendly” sound that’s kind of genre blending, so i get to work closely with them on determine the feel.

Anybody have tips on moving from “mixer” brain to “mastering” brain? 

Asking in the more subtle psychological approach to the art — not what can/can’t be accomplished in mastering. author: hebakadry
content: If however you’re cutting at a plant like GZ media or any of their brokers (which everyone does now) for the high turnaround, where you cannot interface with the cutting engineer…yes you’re going to get a boring “safe cut”…meaning they will not go above and beyond or be creative and will avoid inner diameter distortion at all cost.  They have their own proprietary software and the lathe operator is literally in a different room from the person that actually processes the source material they get for the cut. Very much a setup made for speed factory cutting & efficiency and not so much for the craft.  There is an interesting video by Michael Fremer filmed at GZ…i think he’s the only person that was ever allowed in and it is by all means is an impressive operation.  They have a pretty advanced QC process.  But it’s a game of odds on whether your cut will sound good or not.  Half the time you’ll get a shit cut and the other time it might be fine…depends on which operator you get.  It’s treated like a product there and not so much a “craft”.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I want to clear something up:

People say “your master will get turned down more”.

Yes. If your master is -8 LUFS it’ll get knocked down to -14.


If it’s -13 LUFS…it also gets knocked to -14 LUFS.

So two songs, regardless of their original loudness, will match. 

If you released the same song at two different LUFS, they’d end up sounding “the same” loudness wise after normalization. Not taking into account the compression/saturation that happens with extreme limiting. 


And honestly LUFS works. So just master your shit however it sounds and feels best. Whether that’s -6 or -10 or -16.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Not to get too spicy on here, but I'd like to push back on this attitude a bit.  I think you're massively oversimplifying this. I wholeheartedly agree with your assessment that it's really the creative intent that matter to the record but there is absolutely something to be said in understanding how different LUFS are translating in the streaming environment. 

I'm never making decisions on how hot to master a record with any worry of it getting turned down, etc. But I definitely consider the density I think it should have and how that density will translate in the modern era of how people are listening to records. 

Sometimes it feels like the "just master it how it should be" have missed the subtleties of this....and this is the mastering forum so it's a good place to discuss!

author: Zach Hughes
content: A mix / master of a tune at -6 LUFS normalized to -14 LUFS will sound pretty different than the same tune mix / mastered at -10 LUFS normalized to -14 LUFS. Yes they both end up at -14 LUFS but that doesn't negate the mix / master decisions made to achieve those loudness levels. The later tracks transients will be better preserved and have greater dynamic range. Those two things drastically change how I feel and enjoy music.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I am genuinely curious which points you disagree with. Which do you feel the most strongly about / think is the most interesting?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
This is true (at least as I understand it) but I think the deeper discussion revolves around how dense you want the music to be, how the transients sit relative to other aspects of the music, how much low end you want and what you’re willing to trade off in terms of openness/dynamics vs energy. 

This is a super deep topic that I’m still wrapping my head around and forming my own opinion…and while I know I argued earlier it’s important to consider your loudness, it should absolutely take a back seat to your feel for the music creatively IMO.

There are many complex reasons why people like things loud (some I agree with, some not) but they do and will continue to as far as I can see.

Something like LUFS I find is best rendered as background knowledge. For example I found it interesting Ruairi says he knows how loud a record is because he knows his room so well and doesn’t need to look at the meters. I’m still getting there but I feel that’s a best case scenario so the meters aren’t dictating feel

author: masteredbyjack
content:
We did discuss a bit earlier but I’m not sure I understand your question — I think I read it as you looking into the trade off between turning down a more limited/compressed track (i.e to a dBFS level of like -.5 compared to where others are at) vs leaving the peak level and some more dynamics (which can also make a song sound quieter but in a different way)? 

IMO it’s just a gut feeling/listening game. Both approaches work but have different implications that have to be decided based on artistic intent.

But specifically for albums (and all mastering generally) working off intuition always works so much better for me. This also means you have to sort of practice outside of “game time” so the tools flow when in the moment. Able to work quicker so you keep the entire project in mind. Mastering is a game of trade offs both in songs themselves and between them.

Also IMO “cohesion” is totally overrated in mastering albums. I never care (or even know, honestly) as a listener if song 8 sounds cohesive with song 1. I just care that the arc of the album moves me

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Maybe I worded too strongly! Cohension matters, it's just that I find I care less about it than the feeling of the album if that makes sense. @Nomograph Mastering is way more experienced and knowledgeable than me on this.

I'd also push back against your assumption that every song has to have the same output ceiling. This may be "normal" but sometimes it's just not the move. Just did an album where one song wanted to be more compressed/limited. So we did that but just literally turned down the gain on the output so it fit better with another quieter (more dynamic, not output level) track before it to match the "loudness" of the two more closely.

Hard to give any other insight because so much of it is dependent on the actual songs you have, what the artist's vision is, how to serve that, etc. Dynamics/energy/loudness plays a big part in that!

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But there’s so much subtle stuff to how you make those decisions, like how relative levels feel at low levels vs high listening levels

author: masteredbyjack
content:
What @hyanrarvey and others said...but usually this is used to get a bounce with the compression to make sure it is releasing in time with the groove. In gridded stuff like hip-hop you can actually be really mathematic with it, but generally you don't need to it's about the feel. Of course every compressor is different even with the same "settings"...you can set the attack to let enough transient in and the release to basically make the compressor return to "zero" in time with the movement of the groove. But the release shape, etc will definitely play a role in this too

At least this is how I'm usually using it (though very rarely compressing at all, and when I do I'm using the Weiss DS1-Mk3 plug which has complicated release characteristics). Feel free to correct me if I'm off the mark on this! It is about feel and making the record pump in a pleasing way which can add energy. But of course it's helpful to be very specific about what part of the groove you're actually wanting to bring out (or back) so to me it's hugely about your gut reaction to how the groove moves you

author: masteredbyjack
content: Well I'm not sure if he was wrong or not but my understanding after studying the plugin deeply is that he is...and I don't think limiting based on the bpm to set a release characteristic like that is useful (or at least isn't for me as of now)...or rather just using feel is much more intuitive and better for me

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Wanting to zoom out since there is a lot of software specific stuff recently here…

What is everyone focusing on in the upcoming year?

For me, on the human side it’s continuing to grow the number of projects but also nurturing those relationships better than I have in the past. And overdelivering for people while maintaining a healthy long-term balance in my life

On a technical side it’s taking specific time to dive deep on topics (currently EQ) in a very specific and targeted way for learning but keeping my mastering time very free and intuitive. Only working with things I really understand and come second nature. 

From a philosophical side it’s continually making sure my decision making is based in curiosity and respect for the music rather than fear or concern with how my work is judged

Would love to hear what others are feeling since we have such a wide range of engineers here!

I just think it's a little ridiculous that there's so little accessible info on the nuances of how the digital tools we use work, and even more ridiculous how easily that knowledge hole gets filled up with superstition and then exploited by marketing.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Mainly related to the audibility of things we can’t measure which people dismiss as nonsense (especially when they’re not trained to hear it or don’t bother trying). For this particular thing I’ve repeatedly done blind tests and have no doubt I can hear it but I’ve never managed to measure any difference. I’m now taking a more statistical based approach to analyzing the audio and have been able to see the difference that way which is something people with Audio Precisions and what not have never been able to do (and use their results to “debunk” this). My next step is to develop a deep learning model as a classifier. If it works and can accurately predict if a file is A or B then a lot of people will feel silly for claims they’ve made which show their lack of willingness to consider new ideas because “science”

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I think this is the biggest thing. Sometimes I can tell that a mixer really intentionally used some limiting and it’s a big part of the vibe, they are making very big decisions through it, shaping transients, etc. So why go back from that?

But more often it’s as you said Cian, limiter is just thrown on. And is not creatively essential to the sound and feel.

Again, I am pretty new but I can usually tell pretty quickly when trying to “beat” the ref which category it falls in.

And I’m always trying to do it with my own chain, but sometimes the feel is right there already. It’s certainly never a choice of what is easier, it’s a choice of what feels better to me and which I “believe” more

author: spectrummasters
content: @Nomograph Mastering  hi ruairi so I’m on my third listen to “tunnel under ocean boulevard “ and have been really enjoying it . It’s got a vibe of  a david lynch movie about a singer who is the love child of dusty Springfield and Elvis who grew up with Kate bush on tour with Tom waits and roger waters . Anyhoo I digress ! If I may ask as much as poss without asking you to divulge anything compromising about the process : I am fascinated by a few things and wonder what your approach was . In many parts this work feels almost like a  poetry with orchestration and I think has extended parts with little or quite subtle drum parts . I wonder with something like this how do you judge how hard (or not ) to push the overall level (both individual tracks and all together ) as for me I think I tend to judge off what the drums / bass dictates w/regard to level . In this case where drums and bass aren’t really dominating , I’m not sure I’d be as confident in knowing what is the right level . After all there are periods of soft vocal and very gentle lush strings …..these sorts of passages I might get a bit unsure In . I also wondered did you stay in the box for this one ? ….and was this a project for mostly eq more than comp/limiting ? The sound of the record is v expensive and classic imo , do you treat a record like this completely differently with regards to what processes you might use on a different genre (again ITB vs analogue chains ) . Also , I wondered how long did you have to master this ? I’m v interested by engineers abilities not just to perform but to perform to deadlines . It seems this record could go badly wrong if the right choices aren’t made (where a clipped crushed mix could be more forgiving) I wonder how much time you get to review the moves you make on a project like this and if/when you don’t have much time ….do you ever play it safe ?/ make less bold moves in the absence of time to review them ?

author: ALXCPH
content:
I think that is a little bit of a simple answer. 


Art is something we create to the best of our abilities. If someone feels something is exactly how it should sound, is it not finished or good enough?

Imagine you are a painter, once you are satisfied with your painting you don’t necessarily go to someone else to finish it for you. 

The reason MEs exist was because of technicals and pre pressing duties, usually in-house at labels. But with time the role has shifted to more of a finisher/final set of ears along with some technical knowledge of deliverables.

author: ehutton21

I mean to some extent, sure. As someone in the financial side, I doubt it/am skeptical of it.

AI isn’t gonna fight the IRS about why you such and such a charge that’s almost always gone down as personal actually does go under business expenses.

content: what are y’all’s thoughts/best practices for dealing with stuff that is objectively not ready to be mastered? a buddy of mine (talented guy, but massively under developed in his craft) produced/mixed a tune for a new artist and tasked me with mastering it, which I’m happy to do considering it’s relatively low stakes. my buddy is a total pedestrian at engineering and this thing is click/pop/noise city. I’ve taken it about as far as I can with RX but there’s massive sections where the drums are edited so poorly that beyond normal momentary bad cross fade pop noises, the transients are audibly blurred and doing the whoosh thing. do you guys and gals ever just straight up tell a client that it’s not ready or do you do the best you can with the source material? I don’t think he will be able to zoom in enough with critical ears to hear/fix this stuff, but I don’t want to go back to the artist and tell them that I need to charge more to basically crack open the multitrack/do somebody else’s dirty work.

author: Rollmottle

author: gab
content: Hello! Was just wondering what people's thoughts are on separate streaming + digital masters vs one set of digital masters across both? A mastering engineer I've never worked with before just delivered separate ones (-9 lufs streaming and -5 lufs digital) which I've never seen before and doesn't fill me with the largest amount of confidence - the feeling of the record changes a bit when it's more / less slammed and I feel a bit weird about the idea of two different feeling versions of one record existing in the world. Is there a technical advantage to the separate digital masters approach?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Totally agree with @Rollmottle. I do not have his level of experience, but a -9 vs a -5 master are two totally different records from a creative perspective. They will read different, feel different, and move different.

The “technical advantage”, to my early mastering ear is nonsense. Make great feeling stuff, who cares if it gets turned down or up

Occasionally, if on a super tight deadline or if it’s a relationship I’ve built over time…I’ll give an option…like “here’s my read, but if it’s too vocal forward/much/etc” I’ll give a different option, but that’s generally only in situations where a revision won’t have time or a mixer/artist that I know will appreciate the detail and likes going down a rabbit hole

Okay also circling back here regarding the previous discussion on having previously released songs on a new EP/album...

Have 3-4 projects where I'm finishing them + doing some new masters on them, but they have some previous masters. In different sample rates. Obviously I want to deliver the project in a single sample rate. But we don't want the song to be counted as two separate releases, plays, etc when it goes to streaming.

I'm assuming as long as the files are exactly the same length, when uploaded to streaming and using the same ISRC on the distribution side it shouldn't matter if there is a discrepancy in sample rate right between the "new" master and the previously released one right?

author: Rob Domos
content:
I’m not sure it’s quite that simple. A lot of background SRC happens along various stages of information transfer without our knowledge and it’s not clear how they handle mixed sample rates from various applications being accessible to core audio at once. 

Example of SRC we’re generally unaware of: Airpods run at 48k no matter what, and Spotify is at 44.1  no matter what, so any time spotify is listened to through airpods there’s SRC happening. To make it even worse, if the song you are listening to was uploaded at 48, you’re getting two rounds of conversion. Down to 44 and back up to 48.

Software engineers who can’t hear the difference and value user ease of experience are happy to do this willynilly many times over if it’s convenient from a software perspective. 

With core audio, all applications, which run at different sample rates at the same time, all get summed to one channel in a way that I don’t know or understand that math decisions behind (and I’m not aware of anyone who does know the math decisions behind it, I’d love to chat with anyone who does), and it is then fed to us from that channel. How that’s handled feels like a black box to me

author: cian riordan
content: I may not have your reps, but I have yet to have an album come across my desk that I prep for vinyl that doesn’t sound better with 5 dB less limiting. I get that our line of work is constantly trying to shovel shit rolling down the hill at us, but I think there’s more nuance than “modern records are loud and need to stay loud otherwise they fall apart.” Vinyl isn’t a medium that was designed with -7 or -9 LUFS in mind… and I have yet to hear a vinyl pressing cut in this contemporary fashion that doesn’t sound like a pile of assholes. I have lots of time for serving the client and the project, being a team player and getting things across the line.. but that’s usually the reality of the business... not what’s best for the Sonics. I think vinyl has the opportunity to sound amazing but modern mixing AND mastering techniques are often getting in the way of that.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So I have to make that call in advance, but you've seen how much care i put in on the vinyl test press QC and actually comparing to source files so that closes the loop

author: hebakadry
content: Operator not artisan approach.  Unless it’s cut with someone at a boutique studio they can be more crafty with solving some problems in a limited master to make it feel more vibrant again…but most of the time, that’s the not the case.  Especially with most pop stuff going straight to anonymous factory cuts.

author: hebakadry
content: If you have a relationship with a cutting engineer and a project with a budget for example…have them do a dub either on a song (both cut in the same spot on each side) or a whole side…with limiting and without…or a few dB less where the dynamics remain intact.  And see how you feel about it.  Or run it through simulathe and preview how it sounds on various playback cartridges.

author: Reedy
content: My life circumstances have changed, so my reaction to that mess was basically to stop mixing and go fulltime on this business idea I've been sitting on for a while. Was getting fed up of mixing records I didn't like so my main thing now is to only mix records I like and probably going forward only mix records for people going on my label. Means I can be really selective which works better for me because I've been through so many shit situations in the last 2 years. (This story is one of many). Through everything, I've learned that I care far too much about pleasing the artist and I jumped through way too many hoops to do so. In future, I will give less of a shit. Which sounds like a terrible idea, but really I'm just trying to dial back my obsessive behaviour. In terms of technicals, I learned nothing in the situation, artist could hear something that fucked everything up for them, I could hear nothing, none of my peers could hear what the artist was talking about either. Was only the mastering chain, as the mix was fine. I turned off every plugin individually to get at the issue and it remained. I think it was a combination of things, but I've never had anyone pinpoint the issue before and admittedly I mostly use the same combination of plugins for my mastering jobs (for functionality reasons, not because this specific combination of plugins make the records 'sound' better).

author: JakeTB
content:
One intimidating thing I’ve noticed is that many of my favorite mastering engineers have a greater technical know-how than the average, say, mixer.

Of course the artistic skill trumps the technical, but does that technical knowledge have unique utility in mastering? And is it a prerequisite to being a “legit” ME? 

I always feel weird when people ask “do you master too?”

author: JakeTB
content:
Because the narrative in my head is “of course not, I’ve never cut a vinyl in my life, I’ve never watched a killer ME master a record, I don’t know any of that technical shit, etc.”

But then I see who they’d hire instead, and what they think mastering is, and so feel like I need to step in.

I do think certain record makers can flip between the worlds of mixing and mastering…agree with @Maxim that mixer brain is probably not useful to the mastering approach but there are definitely people that can excel at both, maybe you are one of the unicorns…knowing you and how you speak about records you may well be.

From my end, the approach is different but it’s really just being a record maker with a different mindset and a different box of restrictions…you’re still a record maker. At @Nomograph Mastering level I think there are a whole other set of things that come into play of course, I’m even starting to see it myself as relates to running as a full time mastering only shop

author: Jonathan Jetter

author: Maxim
content:
As always, appreciate your thoughtfulness. I'd also like to follow up by saying that "mixer brain" doesn't serve most mixers well either. it's not a technical pursuit to me. Knowing when to respect magic and where it's coming from is the first skill we should be teaching any technical person.

It's all art and taste which takes years to develop and at this point, it's easy for me to hear when someone tried to make an "engineer's" mix rather than elevate what was cool about the demo. I'm still guilty of making these myself but that's what the delete button is for. I don't know where exactly the cutoff point is switching between the creative/artist brain and the professional engineer mentality (maybe once problem-solving or writing emails). 

But the longer I do this the more it becomes clear to me that when I'm sitting in front of the music itself, feeling what's coming at me and not thinking about my moves is the gig. I don't think that should change at any point. Applies just as much in mastering as it does during the production stage IMO. There's just a different set of constraints at every level that present new opportunities and possibilities.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Curious to get some other mastering engineer's takes on how they handle revisions when the artist wants to swap mix files? I've worked with one mastering eng in the past who charged extra to send a new mix file. What do other folks do?

Two recent examples: I had a mix rev sent back (new file) that the artist told me the bass was turned down a few dB but the mixer had actually turned everything else up a few dB and I also got a BGVs up mix but the lead vocal level was changed and tone altered.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Word. Makes sense. These two examples I just rolled with it and did what needed to be done w/o involving the client further, but I now feel more wary of receiving, in the future, files altered in diff ways than whats been described.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Policy here is that we charge for mix swaps but  I feel like it‘a only ever been applied for major label money no object work or deter a client that is taking advantage. Gotta be less that 5 or 10 times ever

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Oh I make no claim that it’s a norm, just what I do. I expect Sterling charge for mix swaps all day every day

author: esquinalee
content:
Hey y’all, question—
I sent over a Ref for a song at around  -8LUFS  and of course a file with the limiter bypassed along with a photo of my limiter settings to the ME. 

We’re *almost* at a place where we’re happy with the master but some mid resonance is really peaking my ears in the vocals and trumpets that were forward and “on the edge” in my mix but never a problem to comfortably listen to. I mentioned the places where Im wincing at the mid spikes to the ME and he suggested I go into the mix and address those places on the vocal and send it back. 

My worry is that I’ll carve out some of the energy in those places since I’m not actually hearing those areas as problematic until they’re pushed the extra distance in mastering. The master for reference was returned at around -6.8 LUFS and otherwise feels pretty good there but I’m wondering if:

1) I’m hearing my mix fall apart as it’s being pushed harder into the limiter and can and should be preempting this with carving more mids next time
2)This is something the ME’s usually just deal with as a price of playing the loudness game or if the suggestion for me to address it in the mix is reasonable.
3)I should just find another ME for peace of mind so i can stop thinking about this mix 😅
-

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 1) Just make the best sounding mix you can, I wouldn’t try to preempt anything you feel might happen in mastering, it will be a moving target song by song and engineer by engineer

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 2) Hard to answer this definitively, there are situations that require mix tweaks but these days I’m pretty allergic, it’s very rare for me to ask. The thing here is that it will be difficult for you to estimate what to do or how much of it to do without auditioning the mastering chain live. So you might under or overcook your changes

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 3) I can’t answer 3 for you, the goal is to feel great about the master. If you think that’s still possible then carry on, if trust or confidence is damaged then maybe consider a switch

author: esquinalee
content: These are helpful responses, thanks a lot @Nomograph Mastering @Rollmottle 🙏🏼 nice to have some pro takes from outside of the old inner dialogue feedback loop 😀

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't know the answer, but have you tried pushing both limiters to the extreme and comparing how they react? That's where I'd start. Drive them hard at first (with gain compensation to level-match the non-limited version) and then back them off to medium intensity and see how that feels if it's too much.

I'd do this test with a full mix and I'd also do it with something like a simple kick loop or a short impulse so that you can observe the recovery time.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
for what it's worth,

I got a lot of push back from the ME on some notes I had. thought something weird was going on in the midrange and the highs but he insisted that was baked into the mix. 

he later proceeded to to tell me his chain which included 2 multiband comps among some other things and refused to take them off when I suggested it. 

someone offered to do me a solid and redo the mastering free of charge. I passed the message to the artist but they insisted he HAD TO do it since they had already paid and weren't getting a refund + he's a good friend of theirs. 

didn't want to create a big argument with the artist in the chat (ME ignored my calls)  so I told the artist to take some time and listen and if they're honestly happy with how it sounds, they should go ahead and approve it - which they did.

I'm a little bummed out. especially cause I really believe in the artist and what theyre doing and took the gig with quite a bit of loss on my end but like you all said, this has all been a learning experience. on my end I feel like I need to learn how to express my expectations a bit better to artists who might not be well versed on the technical side (their words, not mine).

author: Rollmottle
content:
Sounds like Jonathan is being entrusted to be the or one of the upholders of the sonic vision of these records. In one sense it’s a testament to the trust he’s built with this producer. But it sounds like he’s been put in that position without an explicit conversation. I don’t know that it would really be that awkward of a conversation to talk it out. They might not realize how much work it is for you and it will be good for you guys to realign. 

I too will work with anybody who has the clarity to communicate the intent of the record no matter producer, mixer or artist. Sometimes the mixer is closest to the sonic vision of the record and may also have the relationship with the artist and producer more than me, so I definitely see the value in Cian’s approach too and one that is pretty common for me over here. I’m sure that evolves at different levels.

author: Théo Quayle
content:
Hey yall — Long time listener, first time asker of questions. I just received an odd request from a major and am hoping for some guidance on how to best proceed. 

They’re looking for ISRC encoded high-res “96/24 or higher for each”masters for a few previously approved singles. They then provide a list of UPC codes and some “internal coding” which look to be ISRC codes 🤔 

I’m fine upsampling from 48/24 (although there’s no obvious benefit to this imo) but I’ve only dealt with ISRC’s in the context of a DDP. Are you able to embed ISRC codes to individual audio files like this? If so, how would I best go about doing this? Or should I just deliver the high res WAVs and advise them to embed the ISRC codes via their distributor?

Appreciate any feedback!

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Yo Theo! First off for the group, Theo is totally outstanding at mastering and a wonderful human. 

I’ve never had this request but you can embed the isrc in the wav in Wavelab, or perhaps even mp3tag (which actually edits wavs or whatever) or a similar metadata editing software (looks like mp3tag supports this under “extended tags”)

More experienced peeps feel free to correct if I’m wrong

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Advise that the mixes were 4824 so this is the highest available HD rate. Offer to upsample if they prefer.

author: spectrummasters
content:
......fine folks of the mastering echelons.....i wonder your experiences/impressions on something..
I find more frequently now that the simple act of engaging the limiter on a mix before even any gaining...subtly but profoundly impacts the stereo image and depth of the mix to such an extent that i feel im immediately in a disadvantageous starting point from there on. I find this with Pro L, Izotope Vintage Limiter , Maximiser (in diff modes) and Standard Clip. 
I wonder is tis an experience others here have encountered and if so, how did you mitigate ?

author: spectrummasters
content:
Sorry I may not have articulated that to well , 

Eg . Last night I had a really great  mix to master for someone . Really open warm and great balance , v similar to love galore by Travis scott and sza. I couldn’t help but feel the act of engaging any plug ins , but especially any of my limiters immediately distorted the sense of width  and depth and where objects in the mix were placed. I’ve sensed this a couple of times before  . I sat there for about half an hour going between dual mono and stereo instances of all my limiting  plug ins ….and then sitting there going between different phase modes on my eq and it seemed none of them preserved the dimensions of the mix

author: itMIGHTbeNICK
content:
What do you guys do in situations where you're being asked for a mastering revision when the notes are mix notes and not mastering notes.

Context: I mastered this track where the vocal was clipping by the main hook of the song, gave myself some headroom and got to work and was able to lighlty fix it with some EQ and some RX. Got a call... Hey man it feels like the kick isn't sitting right in the mix, the vocals sound a little peaky overall, and it sounds like the song as a whole just isnt as dynamic as the mix. I let him know exactly what i did and he proceeds to talk with the artists and then tell me they will give me a new mix. 
Mix two, the vocals weren't loud enough throughout the track and yet again was asked what I did in the master to make this happen and why the vocals sounded compressed.
Was then told yet again that this was a mix issue.

We are now on "Final mix 4" and i'm hesitant to even send off another master at this point.

author: Rollmottle
content: might be best to suggest they marinate on it for a few days before calling it "approved"...might root out a few more iterations or it might actually be done. this can all be framed positively and in their best interest (it is) without it sounding like you're frustrated. you can always play the "gonna have to charge you again" card if it keeps happening, but seems like good faith here, maybe just inexperience.

author: itMIGHTbeNICK
content: Yeah! I fully agree! I already let them know at this point I’ve gotta charge for another revision and they approved it. Everyone’s on the same page it seems but I told them this morning “let’s let this mix sit for today and I’ll check back tomorrow to see if everyone’s still on the same page

author: Rollmottle
content:
Are stems not a standard mix deliverable nowadays? Figured it was and assume it’s priced in. Time to raise your rates?

Stem mastering is definitely a thing and the norm in certain genres. I’ve only done it in the rarest of cases as a problem solver, not because it’s better or preferred (I think it’s worse, but it is a tool). This isn’t always possible for every project but this is where having relationships with ME’s you trust come in to play so you can include the master as part of your deliverable to ensure the integrity of the mix.

author: Will Melones
content:
It’s a bummer to hear our hard work get compromised by decisions down the line. I’m not the person to ask, but I feel like we have two options as mixers. 

1.) do our best work, leave it in the capable hands of the artist, and respect their choices—it’s their song, so they’re right, period. 

2.) try our best to educate the artist (which you’ve done well) at the outset. Create a clear plan, provide guidance based on our experience, and see the project through to release (easier to sell someone on quality mastering at the outset or build it into your own rate than to have the discussion at mastering time). This may be too hands-on for some artists. I’m battling with this stuff as well.

Talking indie level here. I realize the approach to label projects is very different.

author: Berlin
content: How much time has passed between Main Master and Sync Versions for any particular project? I just had someone finally come back two years later.

author: Nick Stetina
content:
@masteredbyjack (sees the post time) I can’t tell if you pulled an all nighter or woke up wildly early on a Saturday 😄

Has there been a discussion with the client on what the end destination is for this release and/or expected deliverables are? Great to have worked on and captured the original mixes as masters in their native sample rate, but if this is going to a DSP for streaming, its SRC your masters from the high-res 48k capture to 44k for submission that I’d be focused on, instead of the other way around (upsampling the original 44.1k master to 48k). If the 48k files didn’t get rejected at upload I’d hate to find out what their algorithm sounds like 😬  Better the devil you know, imo.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I’m an early riser haha. Goggins life.

So update — turns out we do have the 48k of the initial so that’s all cool. And I’m close with the producer, so we need 48k and 44k 16bit deliverables (they requested this). All easy.

So problem solved now — but still curious about if people have delivered projects with multiple sample rates as an exercise in learning

@Nick Stetina it’s going to streaming but my default is to deliver the native sample rate the mixes come in at. Most distros take it almost anything, though I’ve seen more requests recently for 44k 16bit for some of these smaller, newer distros. 

Apple will play it (in ALAC) at what’s delivered, yeah Spotify will covert but it’s making an OGG anyway (which we can check in RX) — so my preference (and I’m open to have my mind changed) is to deliver what it was created and mixed at for a lot of reasons. That seems to do great for me so far! Is there a reason you only do 44 (if I’m understanding that right?)

author: Rollmottle
content:
In the “do no harm” or “do the least harm” ethos, I would have upsampled the 44 to 48 and delivered everything at 48 so you maximize the possibility of native lossless playback. 

Can’t say I’ve ever delivered at mixed sample rates because I’ll usually deal with it pre-processing to deliver at a uniform output.

author: Rollmottle
content: Most everything here is going out at 48/24 and 44/24 these days and 44/16 becoming the rarity unless that was the native sample rate or specifically requested.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Delivering multiple sample rates would be a disaster waiting to happen. I’m pretty sure it would bounce back

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I know major labels need the entirely of a project to be at the same sample rate so I would go ahead and SRC the outlier. Sometimes I’ll have albums with 5 X 48k and 5 X 44.1!k and you just have to call it and SRC in one direction

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For indie upload I’m not certain that it matters, it might? But it might also just accept and spit out the mixed sample rates?

author: Berlin
content: Morning y'all. Yes same, I would call it uniform and not mix, personally. It even happens mid album with the same producer mixer for me sometimes. They've been floating me tracks over months and the first one was at 48k, next two at 44,1k, next two were at 88,2k (y thoooooo)... and so on. At this stage of my life, when I start with a new artist or what feels like a new album cycle with a previous artist, I will ask the question at the beginning, and if the answer is "Yes, it's all going toward the next album" then I'll usually roll 48k 24bit from jump and make adjustments along the way and communicate along the way. But when the final program is complete, it's all one deliverable unless they ask for it broken out (they never do).

author: Berlin
content:
Yeah, on the indie side I feel like a mixed bag is fine and distro kid is just happy to collect their $35/yr from whoever they can however they can.

If I submitted a program to universal like that (which I never would), they would definitely be hitting me back asking what is going on haha

author: Maxim
content: Mac and I'm usually at 48khz. For a while I used to match the sample rate of the tracks but I don't care anymore.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Yes and that’s it. Software fills a buffer in memory. Soundcard reads buffer and plays back at rate determined by clock. If software A or software B puts 1010 into that buffer, no difference

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: MEs, just out of curiosity, if you master a song for an artist and they want the whole shabang with instrumental, slowed&verb, sped up, stripped down and whatnot, do you charge full price for each of these or is there some sort of “group discount”?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Almost everywhere I’ve seen charges a smaller fee per alt — say if main master is $100 it’s $25 per alternate version (or whatever the pricing is for a given mastering house)

Why do you ask? Are you being told otherwise?

Sped up/slower and verb might be different though depending on the song and if new mastering is needed on those

Similarly a stripped down version is probably a totally different master, so I could see that as well

author: masteredbyjack
content:
That’s…not surprising then. Though it certainly is possible that a stripped down version with a different arrangement requires different approach, so that would be less surprising

But for like an instrumental, acapella, clean, etc I’ve never seen people charge full rate for that when the mastering is staying the same

author: masteredbyjack
content:
If it’s just the literal master slowed up or sped down I probably wouldn’t even charge for that, but I can see others charging an alt rate. Not a full one (in my personal opinion), others can do what they may

If you slowed it down or sped it up, maybe things would need to be addressed differently, I can’t say (for instance I’m not going to use the same EQ settings on those almost certainly, but if the master is completed then we speed it up different story)

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Full price for each one is rare but not unheard of. Good way to lose customers

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I believe I’ve seen this video, and have a theory (which I feel free to be proven wrong on and I’m sure you know all this, but to jam on it here).

DAW probably can represent the overs fine without clipping, inside it is 32 or 64 bit like @Nomograph Mastering . Then in render to 16 bit the overs just get put to 0 (“quantized”?). So clipped but not digitally distorted…or at least the bad digital distortion we think of

I’ve seen this in quite a few mixes where the limiter is removed on a mix sent to me at 24bit. In fact I’ve seen people “clip” up to 6db unknowingly doing this and it honestly sounds…fine? Like not some wild digital distortion. I was able to get the 32bit print and verify

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s easy to trip out on this stuff, just remember that the first thing that happens to your “pristine” 4416 WAV on Spotify is that is is data compressed to OGG/MP3/AAC, codec overs are baked in nicely, then level norm is applied if activated, then when it hits your iPhone/Apple TV etc it is SRC’d to 48k locally (or on a mac whatever rate you happen to be running)

author: aidanthillmann
content:
Was messing with RX's new Loudness Optimize/Streaming Preview stuff today. So if I'm understanding correctly, it seems like in order to have our masters played as loud as possible through streaming normalization, the quiet sections of the song should be turned up past a certain threshold in order to be included in the integrated loudness reading, with the goal being to decrease the integrated level as much as possible. 

Now I had a song with a filtered guitar loop as the intro, and that part was below the loudness threshold shown in the Loudness Optimization module. It was also showing that only 93% of the song was above the threshold and being included in the loudness reading of -9.5 or so. After I ran it, that intro was being compressed pretty obnoxiously, as well as some other down sections of the song, and the integrated went down to -9.7. So I guess I could have gotten 0.2db of extra loudness through normalization, but the upwards compression just did not sound good.

Wondering what you all think of it? I guess the moral of the story is to pay attention to the quiet sections of your songs and see if you can make them come in a little hotter, but there's obviously a line there of either gain or compression one is willing to make. Super interesting though and insightful to know all this about streaming! I feel like I can make some moves in mixing to accommodate things like this if necessary.

author: aidanthillmann
content: The only thing I can see this being useful for is just seeing where in a song might not be calculated, and see how much I’m potentially losing out on and making a judgement whether I care or not. In my case today I absolutely did not care about 0.2db and it sounded bad anyways! Haha

author: masteredbyjack

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As we here know it’s of course mostly down to arrangement that a given song will sound loud or not for a certain measurement. Yes mixing can get some apparent level, and we should be able to get a little more. As long as it’s not at the expense at the feel of the art.

That’s my issue with the RX thing…it’s optimizing a number and not feel, not what’s moving me

Also important to remember that the streaming services normalize stuff specifically so that songs won’t sound much louder or quieter than one another. So another point to maximize the feel and interest of the music first

(I say this not to the fellow mastering engineers here but to others who peruse)

Just dialing back the bananas synths, machine gun snare and trap hats means you can actually meet the low end

author: Lucky Yu
content: thanks so much for this @Nomograph Mastering!! something I also wanted to ask was, do you recommend hard 24db low-cuts at like <30hz during certain mixes/masters as well to essentially reduce LUFS and get a louder mix? author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
If you have the time then nothing beats RX. The issue with that kind of top end is not how much of it there is, it’s the character. The inharmonic and dense nature of the sound, mostly caused by particular types of clipping and distortion

Pretty much every other tool attenuates based on how much of a given frequency band there is, and so is pretty ineffective - tending to vacillate between not enough and too much

author: Lucky Yu

Will pay extra attention to the 1500-6000 region for sure and focusing on perceived loudness, as I notice the masters of my favorite Sega Bodega tracks are hitting -9LUFS but feel so much louder than my tracks that are hitting -7LUFS.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
For gapless I print a single file with all processing

Then find a zero crossing and split into 2 separate tracks, I don’t do a little fade in or out

Re checking if it worked, iTunes is not a reliable indicator of anything ever, it’s a dead product now

You need to test several things to QC properly, all of these will bite you in the ass at some point

1) Does the end of the first track (from the split file) play cleanly on it’s own

2) Does the second track play cleanly (the start) on its own?

If so great. Now the big caveat 

Streaming services serve up many different types of files - OGG, AAC, MP3, FLAC and ALAC. From memory AAC and MP3 both add small amounts of silence at the start of file when you compress the file, this is done automatically during the data compression (and silence added can even vary depending on codec used and sample rate)

This means that what was a seamless transition between your spliced files will now have a gap, sometimes that creates an audible disturbance, sometimes not

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - Does bit rate effect how long the inserted silences are with MP3 and AAC/M4a - I would suspect so. Can someone do the test today?

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Hey there how's it going!

Just wanted your thoughts on advice on something I'm currently trying to tackle with my own mastering buisness.

Currently on my 2nd year, and at the moment I'm contacting lots of UK dance/electronic labels to try get some consistent work coming in. All is well until the majority of labels I contact all get mastered by the same engineer who charges £10 a track, which I think is such a low rate and seems like a race to the bottom.

Is it worth it at my stage to take on these lower paying gigs? 

My thoughts are:
- It could be damaging to the clients I already work with that pay my full rate.
- These bottom clients will never be full rate if they've had a £10 deal for years
- It gets more work in for me = my name gets spread out a bit more. But, these labels never seem to credit the mastering engineer.

What are your thoughts? What would you do?

Definitely going to pivot what I'm doing and head down the artist/producer/mixer route, you're completely right. Feel like I've wasted a load of time connecting with these small dance/electronic labels.

author: Edsel Holden
Nicky Howard
content:
I completely agree with you that it would be impossible to give feedback on all the different artifacts encountered.

This is more specific. There must be a cause—something like a common vocal plugin or interface that would at least be helpful to advise clients that it could create this. Prevention rather than the cure.

It's like a periodic set of hairline clicks after each phrase. I'm hearing it much more regularly, which is why I wondered if anyone else had encountered it.

I started mastering before RX, and it's now a fully integrated part of the process. Some people certainly choose not to take this route, which is cool if it works for them. 👍

author: Nicky Howard
content:
The dreaded mic'd-up mouse click!

This feels more like a plug-in firing in a few faint clicks when the vocal drops enough in level, periodically in time, almost clock-related.

They're hard to spot, but once you do, you start to hear them all the time.

Maybe it's just something that's  destined for eternal RXing!

author: Will Pragnell
content: I have a track here with a kick that is almost all sub, very few harmonics, and is also way too loud. As it happens, this is a mix that someone wanted feedback on before sending for mastering, so I can help them fix it, but I also took it as an opportunity to do a practice master on the current version. Best results so far have come from setting up a dynamic low shelf in Nova, which helps to take the excessive low end boom out of play, but obviously doesn't do anything to bring out the harmonics higher up and make the kick audible on smaller systems. Any suggestions for other things I could try (other than maybe getting crazy in RX)?

author: Will Pragnell
content: I'm too new to the mastering game to have something to share from that side, but I have sent a lot of my own music to be mastered and always ask for mix notes... my motivation in doing so is always to try to tap in to the fresh (hopefully objective) ears of the ME and see if I can hear something new in the mix that I missed, and turn that in to learnings for better mixes in the future. This is for music that I write, produce, record, and mix all myself, so by the time a mix is done I'm usually way too close to it and have lost all sense of perspective. I imagine if I was a fully fledged mix engineer mixing tracks for producers/artists I'd feel less of a need to do this. Not sure if that perspective is helpful... but maybe?

author: Will Pragnell
content: This is making my head spin a little. I'm not disagreeing with any of the above, but I'm struggling a little to reconcile it with my experience as an artist who has sent mixes off for mastering, asked for notes, and genuinely wanted to be told if there was something like "the kick seems 6db too loud" so that I reevaluate, see if I missed something, think about why that happened, and maybe send a new version of my mix. It feels strange to me to have this perspective as a client (i.e. this is the service I hope to get and am paying for) and then on the other side of the relationship say something like "don't provide this information, even though they asked for it, just do the best master you can". There's a mismatch there that _could_ be interpreted as the ME not providing the service the client wants. Perhaps the contextual difference here is that when I was sending these mixes to mastering, it was not my "career", I didn't have a team, or deadlines, or a label involved. Or perhaps I'm just misunderstanding?

author: Will Pragnell
content: I understand this. The core part of the mastering service is to finish the record, ensure quality, and make it the best version of what it can be. To counter, though, if I explicitly hire an ME and say to them "the reason I'm choosing to pay you for mastering is because I want the mix feedback" (which is something I have 100% done in real life), then the definition of what the service is maybe isn't quite as clear cut

author: Will Pragnell
content: Which is totally fair! Maybe what we're uncovering here is that what I wanted in that context as an artist wasn't really mastering, I wanted mix feedback, and I happened to try to ask mastering engineers for it

author: Zach Hughes
content: I mean pursuit of excellence on a given project. Not to say anyone is going to do anything other than their best work. So more a question of how the work is organized, feedback mechanisms

author: Zach Hughes
content: I guess my question is. I feel silo'd. Is that a feature or a bug?

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Lately I've been feeling that my work is to do the best I can by the people around me, mainly artists, and to help them produce the most excellent work I can. Strategies / tactics of how to do that are growing more and more complex to me. I care about the dreams of the people I work with.

I think it matters to me because the people and the work matter to me.

Does it actually matter? Ya know.. sometimes its easier than I'd like to feel otherwise but yes I do believe it matters. I think humanity is better for it. Woops forgot to hit reply. @Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: How does this relate to feeling siloed?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If their success is a shared goal why does it not feel like a band of brothers and sisters?

author: Zach Hughes
content: In part, I think it comes down to different ideas of how to achieve success. Incentives. False proxies. Varying time horizons. I want to work slower and aim higher. Often those coming through the door seem to feel they must work at greater speed, that they are behind somehow. For context I work mainly with independent artists with very limited resources. I can't get the question 'why don't we all rely on each other more?' out of my head lately. I want for more organization. I want to be on the hook with others who feel likewise.

author: Berlin
content: Yessirrr. I feel the same here. So much goes into a mix or a master to be able to just give blanket feedback, without knowing more!

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Could be several different things, right? Sometimes it's a gap too far to bridge in the moment- I'd love some upper extensions on the harmony but the artist only thinks in triads. Sometimes it's a technical limitation- the rough mix is a mess but I know the producer's assembling the track on Focal Alphas in an untreated room. Sometimes it's a budget limitation or label politics that I'll never know about. Sometimes (often) different people just think about music differently. Sometimes (often) it's none of my business, and I should focus my energy on my part of the job.

Also try to have enough self-awareness to remember that I surely have my own analogous blind spots.

And also 110% believe in empowering one's collaborators, helping people learn and make progress. I just don't think in-the-moment critiques are a helpful part of that.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: My working theory is that limiters are designed to see regular program - sidechains, attack, release etc are all optimized for that kind of input so when you feed it already mashed audio it just reacts and bounces in a very ugly way to me

author: aidanthillmann
content: I have a funny question, but it's something I've always wanted to ask a pro mastering engineer. When I (a mixer) get hired to do a mix/master for an indie client, I often feel like I lack some knowledge about the technical side of *delivering* a proper master. Is there a sort of checklist that I could have in terms of making sure the master file I deliver goes through a similar QC process as a pro master would? Things like dithering, sample and bit rate stuff, fades, and then the realm of things I've never thought about like metadata come to mind. Or an answer could be I shouldn't worry too much about all this and just deliver a file at same sample rate/bit depth as it was and hand over the .wav? Just wondering if I can step up my "mastering" game in a technical sense (quotations because I will never call myself a real mastering engineer lol)

author: aidanthillmann
content:
@masteredbyjack True Peak is definitely a can of worms we don’t need to get in to, but do you have any rules of thumb on how to set a good ceiling level? I feel like the general wisdom is that if peaks aren’t too bad, say over 1db then it isn’t too much to fuss over. That’s all I know haha

@Rollmottle see all the alt passes and any physical release stuff, that’s where I would hope that if a client needs all that they have the budget for a pro. I will draw my line there haha. I think 99/100 clients of mine just want a mastered version of the mix to upload to streaming and that’s it, not even any mastered alt passes or anything else really. So I’m just wondering any best practices for the main master file

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: While I don't do that in the sense of smashing things on 2 limiters I do often use 2 limiters with one only catching occasional peaks. On a lot of what I work on that has tons of low end I might get things feeling good with one limiter but then there might be the occasional peak that makes it crunch up so rather than fussing with it (and making it not work as well for 90% of the time) I'll have another limiter bring down those peaks and get things not crunching. I guess I could use volume automation but that seems much more finicky than just spreading the load on 2 limiters

author: flyboystudio
content:
Awesome, thanks for the feedback. This was the comms via A&R:

“Just taken a look and could you send over non-limited versions?
Headroom is good but looks like they've just turned the output down on the limiter instead of removing it and turning down the master channel level.”

I like to leave a bit of headroom (3db ish) as very occasionally I’ll a/b without the clipper and decide i prefer the mix with it off. I clip individual channels and buses before they hit the mix bus too.

author: flyboystudio
content:
Yeah this was my gut feeling having delivered mixes in a similar state many times previously. 

I’m very conscious of not being too heavy handed anywhere along my signal path, especially with the clipper & limiter. If either are working too hard it tells me I need to go back to the mix and fix.  

I’ll do as you suggested and see what I get back, interested to see how a couple of different versions sound. Thanks again!

author: agnusbeats
content:
Hey folks, first off just wanted to say I’m extremely grateful for stumbling across this group via LWMR - I’ve just been reading through the groups soaking up all the epic conversations, recommendations and knowledge that’s currently being shared!

I’ve recently been getting some feedback on mix + masters and recurrence has been that chorus’ and bigger sections of songs need more stereo width. There is major panning already happening within these tracks… so I’ve been trialing out imaging tools such as S1 imager, Ozone Imager, T-racks imager, Microshift & Doubler. I’m aware it’s important to be cautious with these plug-ins as they can introduce phasing issues. I’m also finding the stereo sound these plug ins are producing sounds - fake, thin, untasteful and feels as thought is alters the song in negative way. 

At times I thought maybe I’m need more instrumentation within these arrangement to play with panning - but I hear absolutely gorgeous tracks that are simply a vocal and an acoustic guitar that have such a rich deep stereo field (almost as if there were 2 acoustic gtr’s) 

I’ve been starting to play with M/S eq and have been having some small wins - but would appreciate and thoughts, views, opinions or direction!

Thanks team 🙏🏼

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Will Pragnell

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Most of the time it’s full rate

author: Nick Stetina
content: Precisely. I saw that rate structure a lot when I got started and adopted it thinking that was just common practice. I eventually came to the same conclusion you did.

author: Rollmottle
content: It's important to charge SOMETHING when you're starting out to establish this as a service you now offer and a business you now operate. That won't be your rate and doesn't have to be, but making it "real" is important. You should probably have a good idea of where you want your rate to be for the first couple of years as you start charging and building a client base.

author: Rollmottle
content: And it will probably look pretty different from what you would charge to master an album today vs. 2 years from now.

author: cian riordan
content: Super fair that you offered for free and they insisted on paying. But I do think unless you’re coming out of an apprenticeship or an assistant position, I think there’s merit in knocking out a few free gigs to work out the kinks in your operation before charging a fee. My opinion, people super welcome to disagree.

author: Rollmottle
content: Agree with this. My post assumes you've worked out those kinks already and are ready to now charge for it, even if it's largely symbolic.

author: Will Pragnell
content: Good advice, thanks. Yeah, I have a rough idea of what I want my rate to be this year (and it's definitely at the low end). My goal is to have enough satisfied clients by the end of the year to feel like I can justify raising it.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: This might be more suited to biz talk but looking specifically for input from mastering engineers where your involvement in a project might just be a few emails rather than months of working closely together - when you have a project with a new client and it's rather painful on your end from not very helpful notes, going back and forth on what they want, thrilled with v1 but just a few "small" notes than ends up with countless revisions, "we liked how the snare sounded in v1 and how the vocals sounded in v2 but v3 had the nicest texture" type comments, etc but it was all pleasant interactions, not tense in any way (at least based on email exchange), and they might thank you afterwards for the great work etc - do you respond back saying "it was great working with you" etc or would you push back and offer some kind of feedback on it not having been a great experience working with them?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Not sure what you mean. Not offering any feedback is going to lead them to make less notes?

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
I've had clients that go crazy with notes in mastering and then calm down on return projects because they eventually realize those are mix things, or the things they want to change aren't actually things that need changing, they mellow out.

I'd rather work through a difficult client and have them realize things like that on their own than be high-friction and give feedback about their feedback.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I agree that most feedback wouldn't lead to them changing anything and would just lead them to go find someone else who will work with them they way they'd like

author: masteredbyjack
content: Tough call, probably more about how much you connect with the music, want to develop the relationship, etc

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Regardless of any feedback you might have regarding workflow, having mixes finished, etc would you ever not respond positively? Or you'd always say it was great working with them?

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: Hi guys, I've been mixing a friend's album and we've done a couple rounds of revisions to everyone's satisfaction- the report back is that everything is sounding good but then all of a sudden there's a bunch of "problems" that get brought up last minute to the tune of "you don't need to worry about this stuff, we'll just have you export stems for a stem mastering". This mindset makes me really nervous, like if they want it brighter and the snare to snap a little more and stuff, that should be handled in the mix. I don't want to do endless revisions, but if you tell me after 4 rounds of revisions there's additional stuff you want changed, I'd rather just do it. Why do a stem master? Feeling like it's getting into the weeds and over-complicating things but maybe I'm missing something about what's expected at the mastering stage

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: I'd be bummed if they took this mix that's feeling  so good and went super heavy-handed with an EDM-style stem master. It's a rock record, very RATM stuff so i don't think it really needs a super polished touch but i guess that's on them

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: I was able to put some Brauer stuff I learned last month with him into play on this record so it's probably the most lively, exciting, and loudest record I've done. I'm really proud of it, I'm thinking that'll come through no matter what the master ends up being because the mix is -8 LUFS and doesn't really feel it. I'm also offering to connect them with the ME i've used for years, who I trust completely, so they might go with him!

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: No, stem mastering was suggested as a means by which an ME could have more control to "shape it to that full radio ready sound, address these issues, and take the burden off [my] plate". Thus my feeling like that was kinda backwards

author: Will Pragnell
content: For mastering projects with more than just one or two tracks, what are folks thoughts on delivering one track before doing the rest, vs the whole lot at once? Thinking about this from the perspective of the client and how it makes them feel and could add / remove confidence. On one side, it gives them an early indication of direction and an early opportunity to give feedback, which some may enjoy. On the other, it could communicate less confidence on the part of the mastering engineer, and I feel like a big part of what we are trying to do here is make them feel confident about releasing the record. Found myself wondering about this over my morning coffee... anyone thought about this much?

author: Will Pragnell

author: Will Pragnell
content: How much are people worrying about mono compatibility in 2025? I know that many small bluetooth speakers, etc. are still summing to mono, so it feels like it matters to me. That said, I'm noticing a lot of recent releases that seem not to care. Latest example is https://tidal.com/browse/track/371179904?u - huge chunks of the strings just dissapear in mono, and looking at a correlation meter while it's playing I can see that it's negative a lot of the time. Would you have let this go out like this? How do you approach it if you get a mix like this? (edit to clarify: not asking about the technical side of how to fix this sort of thing, asking about how you think about this kind of stereo material, how you approach it with clients if you feel it needs changing, etc.)

author: Will Pragnell
content:
Great question. Let me try to answer. I suspect this may be where the learning opportunity lies...

I think what matters to me is that 1) the piece is presented in the best way possible to maximise its impact or essence 2) the piece is listenable and that impact is not lost in a wide range of environments / contexts (i was tempted to say "it translates well" but I think that's a subtly different thing) 3) the client is happy with the result, and feel confident releasing their art, feeling good about it, feeling it's the best version of what it could be.

I think it's point 3 that gives me pause. You can count my paying mastering clients on one hand, so I'm as "beginner level" as it gets, but that said, when i talk to those clients, they share with me that they want a mastering engineer to ensure that their music is going to "sound right on streaming platforms and translate well to lots of systems". There's a lot of FUD about loudness normalisation, LUFS, etc. I don't think it's a huge leap to feel that we should also be thinking about common playback devices such as airpods, and bluetooth speakers. For clients who aren't seasoned mixers or record makers, I wonder how they would feel if they listened to their mastered record on a bluetooth speaker and heard that whole parts had practically vanished. Of course I'm also sensitive to not wanting to introduce doubt in their minds unnecessarily.

author: Will Pragnell
content: I agree that optimizing for mono seem like the wrong way to go, but I feel like there's a spectrum between optimizing for something and giving it no consideration at all. I guess my instinct is to at least _consider_ how it'll sound in mono, but again, I'm brand new at this. Interesting to learn that the wiser folks here aren't as concerned about it

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Big Picture - Sometimes clients give us notes that are to our understanidng obviously wrong. "Hey the bass is distorting" and say we know that that the speaker in their car stereo is busted from the last time we rode in their car. The reflex is to say "no, the master is fine, you are wrong". But if we listen better what they are really saying is "I don't feel like we're finished yet"

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Øra Mastering
content:
Hi, Karl here.
I’ve been a silent reader and it’s been very interesting to read all the different topics discussed here in the mastering channel.

I got an inquiry today that rubbed me the wrong way and I figured this would be a good forum to get some input before I respond.

I run a mastering studio in Trondheim, Norway. It is a small town with a fairly large university (with a lot of tech) compared to the city size. Today I was contacted by a student that also works with Masterchannel, «a company that develops AI-technology for music mastering». They want to rent my studio to record videos of people using their software. They want to know the price for renting it, but they were also open for a trade where I can freely use their photo/video-content to promote my studio 🤓

I do not feel threatened by AI-mastering services in any way as I believe I offer a different service then they do. I also always respond to emails with a positive and helpfull tone, but there are so many ways I could answer this one.

How would you respond in a civil way, but kind of get the point across? Don’t want to be rude, just kindly decline and give them a few pointers on why I don’t want to be affiliated with an AI-mastering service.

author: Paris Lee
content:
@Stefan 
I don’t audition different converters on every track. That would drive me insane. 
For an album that would be more of a thing…but I’ll be honest I’ll just use one converter for a while across some projects and then I’ll switch to the other one arbitrarily for a while…

(I have a Crane Song Interstellar and a Lavry Savitr
Both great All Rounders that have proven legacies  and hard to get a bad sound out of…)

I’m not a big believer that the converter is the ‘barrier’ to delivering your best work. If you’re in a room where you’re hearing what’s happening clearly, you can work. Now we all have our preferences on that ‘last 5 percent’ of sonics, which influences your decision, but if I can hear the eq and get a cohesive tight image and strong center, it doesn’t matter, I’m fine. All of that is Much more important. 

These converters are all so fucking good now. I think 15 years ago which one you had was more of a heated discussion. 

Just don’t feel the need to go off the reservation on the ones you’ve seen in the top guys racks over the years, and…DONT BUT SOME VINTAGE THING THAT COULD BREAK ON YOU!!! Get something new that’s supported. 

Maybe I over answered haha. Coffee ya know

author: Beck Nebel
content:
Hey mastering dogs – I’ve been moving toward a career in mastering, encouraged by friends and feeling like it could be my long-term path. But I still feel pulled toward production and mixing—I worry I’ll miss that spark of being part of creating something truly great.

Right now, I’m fortunate to work on music full-time, splitting my time between producing, writing, mixing, and a slow trickle of mastering clients I’ve been reaching out to. I’d love to shift more toward mastering, but I still rely on production/mixing gigs to make ends meet.

I know being multifaceted is important, but I worry that offering too much could make people trust my mastering skills less. When I see engineers who produce, mix, and master, I tend to assume they aren’t great at mastering (maybe unfairly).

I’m early in this journey and may be overthinking. Anyone been through something similar? Do you still get that spark of excitement when working on something truly great?

author: Jasper Boogaard
content:
I’m currently in a place where I’m a recording/performing artist 30% of the time, mastering 30% and doing other audio jobs (editing, mixing commercials, the occasional recording/mix projects) 40%.

I’m in a similar boat where I’d like the mastering to be a more major part of my income, but don’t feel quite ready to say no to other projects (also not a financial option for me either). 

Mastering gives me a lot of spark, I love that moment when a song gets that extra 5% and it gets approved on first pass. I also feel like it might be something that fits me more than mixing. 

Playing and writing music with great folks will be always be my biggest love but I’m not someone who wants te be on the road for weeks on end, and the type of music I make is not likely to generate a steady income. 

In the future I’d like the percentage to be 30% artist, 60% mastering with the occasional odd project if it’s a fun/exciting project. I guess I’m not sure if I have a helpful insight here but I feel you for sure and have had similar thoughts lately.

author: mcsnare
content:
Hip hop is almost unique in the limiting being a huge technical aspect of the genre. I continue to master hip hop although I have not as of yet, cut any. 
My standard procedure for making a digital master for lacquer cutting is simply to render the sides without limiting. 
Ive have had exactly one client that thought the test pressing sounded too dynamic so I resent the files but with some limiting retained although not the full monte. If you heard the music you would have NEVER guessed this twist in the story. 
@hebakadry is correct that highs are a bigger deal. I guess the point is every project has unique characteristics that require the person cutting it to sometimes make decisions that blur technical and artistic ones together. This is partly why I have a policy of cutting only masters I’ve done. I feel I have the liberty of eq’ing some more at cutting time. 
So as far as the comments go, nobody is totally wrong - it’s simply very situation dependent. I would advise a few things:.
