author: VESHZA
content:
yo mastering friendsss 🎛️
question for yall - how do you manage expectations for mastering with artists?
i usually ask what/if they feel is missing in the track, or what they like or dislike soundwise, and then i take extra notice for it to after i listen to it myself, and figure out if the artist is coming to me more with a heavy-lifting mindset, or a please-barely-touch it mindset if that make sense

but everyonce in a while a get artists going the opposite direction from what they initially tell me,
for example - i just had someone saying he really likes how his track sounds and wants to keep it as is in terms of overall balance so i did that, with very gentle touches, and he then asked if i could brighten it up more and also beef the lows, he was really happy with it on version 3 where i boosted around 4dB at 60hz lol (sounded fairly different from the original mix he sent that he said he loved)

do you guys just see it naturally as a part of the mastering process? or is there something you think could be done better to nail it easier right from the get go?

author: Paris Lee
content:
Gaining trust with the artist is so important 
If Artists are in LA (when I have time) I always encourage them to come to my studio to play their mixes. When they’re in my environment, I find it’s easier to have conversations on the record, and what Im feeling about it and what they feel about it . Even a phone conversation, not even about the track necessarily, but just shooting the shit and them getting to know you, helps a TON with these types of situations when come up. 
Human connection is everything in the service industry. A lot of people are too busy to talk. And in some cases for legitimate reasons. My clients appreciate that they can reach me, text me etc without dealing with middlemen. When a client feels like they’re sent something off and aren’t getting what they expect out of communication, and THEN getting back something they don’t like. THATS where things go left! 

I don’t get fired that often, but like a breakup in a way, I can predict in the way we are communicating pretty much 90 percent of the time that it’s not gonna work out for whatever reason

author: Rollmottle
content: You could downsample to 192, work there and then proceed accordingly. At least that way you’re staying at one native sample  rate and avoiding an extra SRC. Probably wouldn’t make a huge difference either way though.

author: allearsmastering
content: yes thank you for the info you share as usual its priceless! since i started following your advice and using one eq a clipper and a limiter I work faster and my clients are much happier with the masters less revisions which is great! Sometimes I need to really limit like 5-6dB of gain reduction and that scares me a lot! At the moment I find that clipping a bit more aggressively before the limiter makes for a cleaner more musical result for the majority of the time rather than relying heavily on the limiter. The music feels more connected. So far I find the Pro L2 in All Round mode being the most transparent limiter followed by the balanced mode in ozone maximiser but as always depends on the song. Again thank you Ruairi and everyone else for all the info you share on here! Really appreciate it!

author: vostral
content:
I just export/ render a master at two different sample rates. 48k (original project SR) and 96k (for experimenting). And the result is the 96k master has more powerful and solid low end, which i'm pretty into and surprised too. 

How is that possible???

FYI, i have turned on oversampling in the clippers and limiter

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Several possible mechanisms for the change

- Less aliasing (making things feeling more weighty)
- The sound of the oversampling filters (blurring top end transients and "smoothing" the lows)
- A bug/difference in how a plug in is working at the new sample rate

If Just SRCing to 96k was a free lunch we'd all be doing it every day, so it's worth trying to understand the reaons for what you hear. That way you can employ it when appropriate in the future

author: Berlin

author: Rollmottle
content:
Not my preferred way of working as a “mastering engineer” but have done it and it’s fine. But I also am comfortable in a production and mix context. I don’t know that I’d call it mastering but it also doesn’t really matter if you get the record across the line. 

The idea that the ME wants or needs more creative freedom as a matter of course, therefore leave decisions of the shape of the record to them, I find to be somewhat dubious. I don’t feel constrained by playing my role as an ME.

author: An Hero
content:
I'm not sure if I presented myself incorrectly, so firstly I'd like to apologize for any discomfort I might have caused. 

I posted a video in good faith assuming we all agree that generalization is not a productive mentality in a learning space. Regardless of how I or others feel about Mr. Whitesea's videos are irrelevant in my (now clarified) context, and it was in an effort to point out and place a feeler for where we all stand on loudness partially as a creative choice. 

I have been trapped in an echo chamber for the majority of my career, looking for a community that shares this belief, one that chooses open mindedness over "ass kissing" as it were. Regardless of credits or accomplishments, I'm not here to step on anyone's ego nor am I trying to involve my own. However, while I agree experience does play a role in subjectivity I chose to remain partially anonymous on purpose, as that shouldn't matter ***at all*** when speaking objectively which I assure you was my goal. Again, I offer my apologies and I would like to reiterate that the point of sharing that video is simply to highlight that the notion of "loudness as a creative choice" is a step in the right direction.

author: Paris Lee
content:
A joy to listen to. It has a mellow sheen that’s got a perfect presence  that does *not* digititis mix elements from 3-10k. *Especially percussive ones*
That hot bright snare sample that kicks up your anxiety level and inflames your tinnitus asserts itself as being what it is, but is free of those extra panic attack additives

You are unshackled-less afraid to eq certain areas that evoke ptsd that other converters have baked into you. That 8x oversampling setting might be wrong, but the aliasing is not fucking up your whole day and making you reach for a Xanax 

Very easy to concentrate on the music and feel relaxed doing it. No notes. 

We’ll see if the benchmark stays. Not part of the ‘master plan’ i just don’t have trs xlr cables for the other RME da pair. 
But we all know the DAC 3 kicks ass so no complaints at all pitching with it right now…

author: Circul & Eas
content:
It's great to hear these experienced perspectives. It's not usually what I 'want' to do , honestly. I want to create those honest feedback relationships, or at least open the dialogue and ask about certain issues, talk with the mixer/artist about what they want, etc, in order to dig in a bit more. But I'm recognizing that this kind of approach also ends up digging holes into my pay-to-time-spent-working-on-a-project ratio. And I do see the point that what people usually actually want from a ME is someone who will take their baby and make sure it's all good and just help them get it out the door. 

I feel like I want to make thing more complicated and context-dependent. But many of you are saying that I should mostly treat this like emotional support, rather than technical support, in most circumstances. 

It makes me think of how I've learned to turn off my own technically minded 'problem-solving' approach to life issues when I'm trying to support my wife - who just gets annoyed when I try to brainstorm solutions to her problems, and actually just wants to be emotionally supported. I find it super hard to do this, and I have to consciously hold my tongue and say and do all sorts of things to provide her with what she wants, rather than what I would naturally do.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-4EDhdAHrOg

author: Paris Lee
content:
I just mastered a song with a slammed mix and slammed to hell ref, mixed by one of the main assistants of a mixer who is a household name. 

I said nothing. Had doubts that the level was right for the track, but the mix i got had all what i felt was not my ‘taste’ baked in anyway…

So time to flip the burger…
Delivered it a half db lower than the ref -6.7 LUFS integrated, but eliminated the rumble they missed, slightly widened (like 2 percent) above 100-200hz somewhere,  narrowed below 14 percent for a more focused feel of the slam drum impact while the width was allowed to breathe…and some eq…
Referenced the ref. Felt it felt better sent it back. 

Producer liked it and then comes the classic ‘well what did you think it was too slammed?’ Then we kinda fall into the conversation…”i mean…i dunno…the loudness of the ref was a lot…i might not have gone that much…” 

which sparks the “no man you do you! Master to where you feel is right! Forget the ref! Should we call the mixer to change it for you and give you more headroom??” 
This is where you really have to be careful and really explain it out. Because I don’t know how the mix was constructed. I also know that clients will tell you we want it dynamic till you’re blue in the face, but usually that’s bullshit (not like intentional bullshit…but 8/10 you’ll do it and they’ll want you to make it louder again…)

Where am i going with the this…it’s always important to stress to the client when they ask you ‘can we do better. What do you think. What should i tell the mixer to do…etc…*never* make any guarantees about *anything*. Always preface your statement with ‘unless we actually go through the process of doing it again, we won’t really know! It may, it may not.  That’s really the truth. And lay out the state of play as it is. “If we were to do it again…lay out all the variables that need to be considered- how the mixbus was constructed for one…and stay out of The business of giving the mixer edicts.

author: conordalton
content:
I feel like I can hear a difference between different dither types. So if I can hear the difference between different dither types then I can hear the dither or at least the effect of the dither on the song (sometimes) 

The question is if the quantization distortion is more or less audible than the dither noise at loud sections of the song, and if the quantization distortion is less audible than the dither then it makes a case for automating the dither to when it’s actually necessary (the quiet sections of the song)

But that’s at the limit of my understanding and knowledge on the subject so I welcome your thoughts and experience about it

author: Rob Domos
content:
Let’s say you have a vocal and an instrumental that are both very “unbalanced” in a traditional sense frequency response wise in opposite directions. 

If you make the vocal feel good and human, the overall balance of the record will be very lumpy, and if you make the overall balance of the record sit in a place that feels balanced, the vocal will feel cheap and janky.

I don’t think there’s going to be any hard and fast rules because every record is different and navigating those vibe tradeoffs in relationship to the intention of the music is a part of the job, but I’m curious if anyone has any insights, philosophical or otherwise for this somewhat common occurrence. (Doesn’t have to be about the vocal but it is for me on this album)

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I would lean into it in one direction or the other and make it work. Make cheap and janky feel intentional

author: masteredbyjack
content:
When I hear things that are outside of the “norm”, unbalanced, messy, whatever in a cool way (even if it wasn’t necessarily intended) I’m definitely more likely to take it further in that direction than back towards balanced or whatever you’d call it.

It’s pretty common for someone to ask something along the lines of “I think x is sticking out too much” and me to say “yeah that’s what I like about it”

Curious if others feel the same

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I'll generally let mix revisions slide without any extra fees but I've had a couple of not so great experiences lately where after the 3rd mix revision I mentioned that I typically charge a fee for that and then the client was shocked since they didn't know about this on previous projects and seems like a new development. Even trying to put it nicely and still waving the fee I feel like it's put a strain on some relationships. Largely why I'll usually let it slide. Not sure if I should be including that with my rate

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: With labels it’s not a problem since they generally expect it so it’s generally smaller indie projects where I run into problems and even if I just mention that on future projects it’s something I’ll potentially need to charge for, it’s been an issue

author: Halliemmelton
content:
I have a big question and maybe there would be a better “general” thread for it but would love anyone’s insight.

I just remastered an album for an artist—not gonna say who mastered it the first time, the masters aren’t bad and the mastering house has a great reputation—but the new masters are without a doubt more engaging and bring the intent of the record forward a lot more. I think it’s in part because have a more personal relationship with the artist and could dig in harder knowing their intentions.

I’ll lead with—I’m biased af. Not because of my masters or anything, just because of my relationship with the artist and how I want them to do well. 

The single I mastered for the artist did really well streaming, and this previous (imho really amazing, again I’m biased) record had kinda flopped—def didn’t get the attention it deserved, and it got zero playlisting—I’m talking less thank 25k streams compared to the single’s 300k streams. 

I really love the record and do not think it got the chance it deserved. 

The artist loves the new masters, and we’re now chatting about resubmitting these new masters—if we swap out, it feels like there’s zero chance to reconsider playlisting? In theory I know playlisting may not make a difference, but the single’s stream counts make us feel like it’s important enough to consider. The album was released in 2022, so re-releasing it as a different version is definitely an option as well—but curious if any of you have any experience in remasters/rereleases etc and have any opinions or advice on different ways this could be handled!

author: Paris Lee
content:
I’ve said this before on this forum but since we’re back on the subject 
If you’re gonna try to tell the mixer what to do, and can’t back it up on exactly how then don’t say shit. I don’t mix never have, and if i said something it’s inevitably “how do i fix it? And i have no good answer for that… so i don’t do it

BUT…my vibe is being in the room with my clients while we’re working and just explaining my process and what I’m hearing and affecting the audio and it’s WAY EASIER, when they get the idea of what’s happening in a good room, it’s *much^ easier to be on the same page and get into a collaborative groove and give them an open forum and an sense of equality with me -and they feel empowered to speak the fuck up and tell you no no no go back the other direction. If there’s too much sub, they’ll hear it themselves…if it’s bright as fuck…same…
And then to watch you FIX IT, you get clients for life that way
The technology we have to makes this process feasible remotely as well and that’s only going to get better

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
Sometimes, I'm wondering what exactly happens when the gain reduction graph in Pro-L2 is not returning to unity and shows, for example, 1 or 2 dBs of "constant reduction" in between peaks. (Like in the picture attached.)

I used to avoid this kind of situation, thinking I was just reducing the whole volume of the track by 1 or 2 dBs, but judging by ear, and listening to the delta channel, it does not seem to be true. It feels more like I'm engaging the "clipping stage" a bit more (if we can call it this way).
It seems like above 3dBs of "constant limiting", then, the loudness hit a ceiling, and the volume is reduced proportionally. (Apparently this behavior change a bit across the different algorithms) 

Am I missing something ?
Should I stop paying attention to this graph, and use the "compact mode" of the GUI ? 🙂

From the cultural impact, history, artist, lyrics, production, mixing, influences, influenees, where each craft was at that given time and how it all came together as this authentic, artistic, impactful, cathartic, real, and all while staying commercially viable? author: spectrummasters
content:
Thank you for your reply Ruairi . I hear you and think we are coming at it from two different places but I really admire and respect your perspective . 

My perspective on the OP’s question is informed somewhat by my other engineering work .  The dynamic feels very familiar.

I’m used to a competency-based hierarchy but where work gets critiqued constantly, regardless of who did it or who knows who. We focus on solving the issue in front of us, not protecting reputations. The work stands on its own, and separating critique from personal loyalty keeps things efficient and professional. 

In this regard , I feel that one’s honest impression of someone’s work shouldn’t be taken ad hominem and as a slight …. Because ultimately that part isn’t of any engineering utility . 

I love and agree with you about meeting the music and I also value above all things that people are not made to feel scared or risk humiliation for asking a question “in class “ . That actually makes me sad  

Again , Thanks for expanding on your view ruairi.  

I always enjoy a discussion

author: aliberger
content: hey all, i have a q about order of operations for SRC & bit depth reduction when turning in masters for different formats, which somehow i'm doing for a client for the first time today. the premasters for this project came in at 24/48 except for two remixes at 24/44. i did the digital masters at the original sample rates, they've been approved and now i also need to send 16/44 for a cd and 24/48 as 2 full sides for a tape

author: aliberger
content: those two null down to like -120db, so i feel pretty safe going from the 24 bit ones in that regard

author: aliberger
content: totally. i guess another possible element at play is that i'm usually sent things at 44 or 48 and working at that sample rate, so (i think?) maybe i'm getting more frequent and/or higher true peaks than i would if working at a higher rate?

author: Berlin
content:
If you want you can implement 2x oversampling to help mitigate ISP a little, but if you wanted a little more control, you can upsample and work at that high sample rate. Export at that higher sample rate, and 32bit float.

SRC and Dither using RX for your various formats.

Reassemble in your DAW for each program. i.e. Main Master, DDP, or Vinyl Premaster.

Find a workflow that works for
you.

Lots of folks don’t worry about these things and just export, listen and party. 🎉

author: DarrenB
content: This is a good point.  I definitely remember a time when GS lore was to 'let the mastering engineer finish it'. I admit in the past feeling like I should always be doing something, but then there was a great MWTM with Randy Merrill where he did small but extremely tasteful moves that elevated but didn't rebuild the songs. author: DarrenB
content: It's always a tough battle of ego vs ears.  I feel lucky that I've been able to use all the baller things people talk about, demystifies them a bit, helped remove GAS and turned the light back on me, they didn't automatically make magic songs or masters as some would have you believe.  That switch of default from 'must have or run thru this gear' to 'let's listen and see what's going on before doing anything' helps immensely.

content: Tbf it’s also a feedback loop. If your experience with mastering is someone sending back four versions, one of which is identical to the mix and the other three are probably worse than the mix, you might also think mastering is a scam

author: Mike Tierney
content: I think especially if it’s a single this is unfortunately my take as well. We’ve all had enough bad experiences with mastering to see the red flags. But then, that also feeds into the dialogue of “mastering doesn’t matter” so idk. It’s a hard time out there

author: hebakadry
content: When it’s worked and the client came away super stoked, that makes it all worth it for me.  Lately, most of the stem work I do is with international artists who self mix, where the exchange rate makes it very hard to hire outside mixers, if they’re hard to find for the particular genre they oscillate in.  So even if I wanted to recommend a mixer it’s not really in the cards and I gotta step in and help out.  Which I’m super happy to…when it’s right.

author: East End
content: And at the price point these are at, if I’m not using all the features, it’s a tough pill to swallow
